Eventually, they begin their journey, but a horrific, unexpected event leaves them with a body to hide, shed-loads of guilt/disgust/pain to try and shut away and a long, arduous journey down the rocky river back to the brink of sanity. It's intense, disturbing and heart-pounding for a long duration of the film, but the real horror comes from the pre-insanity section of the film, where the character's isolation from familiar forms of humanity and clear lack of enthusiasm or knowledge of how to canoe down an incredibly wild river in an unknown land is truly unsettling. I didn't quite believe one or two scenes (Jon Voight's sudden and near impossible rock climb) and the pacing was a bit too messy but overall this is an incredible experience. Looks beautiful, brilliant performances and I've already said this once, but is absolutely shocking and disturbing to this day. Boorman may have had an incredibly inconsistent career, but this film alone grants him a certain level of cinematic integrity. The early 70s sure were exciting times for cinema!

Deliverance sets itself apart from thrillers of a similar vein in the way that it totally subverts the genre and the types of men portrayed in this. The premise starts off simply, with a group of alpha males going for a canoe ride in the woodlands, but things take an expectedly dark turn. The narrative plays out in a standard way, but it goes to such deeper and more intricate lengths, particularly in it's display of violence. Here violence is taken to a level of brutality and shown in it's full glory, sinking deep into the brain and residing there.I think the film unfortunately peaks too early, with the infamous pig scene coming around the forty minute mark and that dug itself so deep inside of me that nothing that came after it could really compare. I think that the film really deconstructs these alpha male types and throws them through the ringer, pushing the audience through it with them. Particularly in the Jon Voight character I admired the way that they brought a lot more depth to him than I would have expected. There's this pacifism to him, where even in a kill-or-be-killed situation he's still hesitant to commit an act of violence, that I think spoke a lot truer to humanity than most thrillers do.After that infamous scene, though, it becomes kind of a standard thriller until the final act. Which was a good idea but given how brief the final act was, it didn't have as big of an impact as it should have. I think the film would have benefited from at least another half hour or so of the aftermath, instead of just a few quick scenes before disappearing. The ending though, is genius and at first felt a little too typical but the more I think about it the more I appreciate how simple and bluntly they let the audience know that this experience is never going to stop haunting these men.

DeliveranceDeliverance is probably the best adventure movie I've ever seen. It stars Jon Voight, Burt Reynolds, Ned Beatty, and Ronny Cox. A movie that has been influenced many times since its incarnation from book to movie in the year 1972, this is a movie that fully deserves a spot in the Top 250.Plot: The movie is based on the James Dickey novel of the same name. While I haven't read Deliverance, it is one my list of books to read because this movie's story was great and history has taught us that books have better stories than their movie. This is the movie that has given people the fear of wilderness, stereotypical rednecks and mountain people (no offense), and the idea of rape. This movie is scary without being a horror film and using realistic ideas. That makes it scary.Acting: When the Academy Awards came around, Deliverance was definitely overlooked when it came to acting. Yes there was Marlon Brando for The Godfather but it didn't even get nominations. Jon Voight gave a fantastic performance as a man who is going along for the ride and helps his friends. The real show comes from Burt Reynolds who plays a wild adventurous risk taker who can at times be very reckless. This is where the nomination should have come in.Genre/Quality: This fits an adventure film as well as a scary thriller. As I said earlier this is one of the few non-horror films that manages to scare almost everyone who watches it. This movie's quality shows to anyone who knows a good film. This movie has great cinematography and uses the environment as a great advantage. He takes a hostile environment and makes it look very beautiful and it is very deceptive which is exactly what we want to see in a movie. Some of cinema's greatest scenes in history took place in this movie such as the world famous, "Dueling Banjos," and the famous "assault" sequence. Camera angles were fantastic with great views of everything that is going on and great rafting sequences.Overall this is one of the very best adventure movies I've ever seen. I'm still amazed it doesn't have an open spot in the Top 250. I'm hoping that it will soon find a throne. This movie has had many movies influenced by it such as the fabulous, "The Descent" and many parodies from such great shows as The Simpsons.10/10

One of my favorite movies to date starts as an adventure through the wild side of a team of four men from Atlanta. The idea of living the Chulawasse river before it's turned into a lake comes from Burt Reynold's Lewis, who unconsciously drowns his fellas into their worst nightmare. But if the first half of the film appears rather like an action movie, the second half carries the viewer into a totally different story, with our men forced to make a decision that (they know) will change their lives forever. In very bad ways. At the end of the movie, each person is gonna be forced to deal with the scars of what had just to be a quite week-end on the river but muted into a fight for survival. The movie (except some pretty evident goofs) is very well directed and beautifully shot into a paradise of nature that steals your breath. The photography is excellent as well. Voight, Reynolds, Cox and Beatty are all excellent in showing how a single event can ruin in different ways four different lives only tied to the same mistake.

reviews.review_title: A Thriller with Something Worthwhile to Say
reviews.content: Four middle-class Atlanta citizens travel to a remote, hilly and densely wooded part of Georgia for a canoe trip along the Cahulawassee River before the area is flooded by a dam. The first half-hour or so of the film is peaceful and pastoral in character, with the scenery of the area lovingly photographed, and the friends spend their time hunting, fishing and shooting the white-water rapids on the river. Then the tone of the film abruptly changes when two of the adventurers meet two unfriendly locals. They are threatened at gunpoint, tied up and one of them is subjected to a homosexual rape. Just when it seems that they are about to be killed, they are saved by the arrival of their two companions, who kill one of the mountain men with a bow and arrow and drive off the other.What had started off as an adventure now turns into a nightmare. The four have to try and escape, terrified that the surviving mountain man will return seeking revenge. The river, once their playground, now seems like their prison. The rapids mean that they cannot return upstream, so the only way they can get out is by climbing the steep cliffs of the gorge through which the river passes or by pressing onwards though even more dangerous rapids. (A more recent thriller, "The River Wild", has exploited a similar situation).Tensions arise within the group as they quarrel about how best to proceed and whether to report the man's death to the authorities.This was one of a number of films that were made possible by the relaxation in the sixties and seventies of the cinema's strict code of morality but which seemed deeply shocking. What caused the controversy here was not so much the killing (there is less bloodshed than in the average Western, and certainly less than in the average war film) as the scene of the homosexual assault. Until the sixties any direct mention of homosexuality was virtually taboo, and a scene like this one would have been unthinkable. Many of those films seemed ground-breaking then but look very dated today, generally those which were deliberately made as erotica (like the "Emmanuelle" series) or for their shock value (like "Caligula"). Some directors, however, including John Boorman, used the freedom given by the liberalisation of censorship restrictions for serious purposes.In some respects "Deliverance" is similar to another controversial film made the previous year, Sam Peckinpah's "Straw Dogs". In that film too there is a clash between urban and rural lifestyles, a confrontation which turns violent as the city-dwellers defend themselves against hostile rustics, and a controversial rape scene. Both Peckinpah and Boorman intended their films to make a statement about violence, and both looked at the subject not from the viewpoint of the original perpetrators but from the viewpoint of victims who themselves resort to violence in retaliation or self-defence. "Deliverance", however, is in my view the better film. Whereas the battle between Dustin Hoffman and his attackers in "Straw Dogs" always seems implausible, Boorman makes the four men's predicament seem frighteningly real.Another reason why "Deliverance" succeeds is the excellent acting of the four principals, especially Burt Reynolds and Jon Voight. This is important because the four main characters are all individualised. Reynolds's character Lewis, self-assured and confident, starts off as the leader of the group, but can be complacent and self-satisfied, underestimating the potential dangers of their situation. He is strongly against to informing the police about the killing, and in this he is opposed by the more liberal Drew who believes in sticking to the letter of the law. Bobby, the victim of the rape, is traumatised by his experience. Voight's character, Ed, is initially reserved and timid, but emerges as the leader after Lewis is injured. At first he is either too compassionate or too timid to kill a deer, but later finds himself capable of killing a man. (Reynolds's performance came as a revelation to me, as previously I had simply regarded him as the mustachioed embodiment of seventies machismo).On one level, "Deliverance" is an exciting and very tense thriller (and a very good one as well). There is, however, more to it than that. The film is also about character, a study in leadership, of the changing dynamics within the small group, and of how men react to danger, whether that danger comes from others or from the forces of nature. It touches on themes of the male psyche, of violence in society and of man's relationship to nature. A very good film indeed. 8/10

reviews.review_title: Sometimes you have to get lost before you find something. Like a raging backwoods and river terror!
reviews.content: 1972's "Deliverance" was well done by John Boorman and certainly has to rank as one of the most frightening films of all time. You have four southern men(Jon Voight, Burt Reynolds, Ned Beatty, and Ronny Cox) who are all businessmen and friends who decide to take a rafting trip in the south in a backwoods river. So all decide on the "Cahulawassee" river which is special because soon it will be destroyed when a new and better electrical dam is built, so this is the last chance to river raft the famous Cahulawassee. From the beginning the four men find this territory is very different as it only consist of rednecks, hillbillies, and mountain men. And these people live very different ways of life who are not used to civilization. Only the four men discover after their raft trip begins in a raging river, the backwoods become terror as these hillbillies turn out to be their worst nightmares! The woods scene with Ned Beatty stripping down and being made squeal like a pig is just terrifying and frightening and this particular scene is long remembered and has it's place in pop culture. This film is certainly a classic a thumbs up for John Boorman who really showed that when people explore unknown territories you never really know what you may find and sometimes it turns out to be frightening terror.

reviews.review_title: One of the ten greatest movies of all time
reviews.content: I first saw this film in its theatrical release in 1972 while I was in the US Air Force. At that time I was stationed in Florida where I and several friends would do weekend canoeing. I can assure you that this movie had a profound effect on all of us. I believe that this movie represents what Hollywood is capable of when they put their mind to it. It is a true work of art. It is one of a hand full of movies that are perfect in my estimation. One of the reasons which make it so profound is that all of the events are totally plausible. Another is the reality of the characters. The machismo of of the Burt Reynolds character, the ackwardness of the the Ned Beatty character as he tries to fit in are all people who I have known. I have also known people who looked and acted like the "toothless man and Don Job" as well. I watch this movie at least several times a year and never tire of it.

This movies gained a legendary status as one of the best movie of all time. I heard a lot of actors in interviews mentioning this.
Still becouse its the best movie Boorman ever made I was heavily disappointed by not achieving this level further on in his career as director.The story is about a few friends who go on a rafting trip down the most dangerous rivers in the US. Despite of the strange warnings in the beginning they start the trip. This has deadly concequences...

reviews.review_title: Eerie conversation between a guitar and a Banjo
reviews.content: Last night I had coffee at a mate's of mine and he said he taped Deliverance of Foxtel, would we want to watch it? - "Oh that terrible movie with the wonderful banjo bit, Yes I would!" ...At "THAT" particular scene my wife feeling very undignified yelled out "what are we watching?" - Silence all around, we kept watching. And the story went on. It's difficult not to associate Duelling Banjo with Deliverance, really they belong to each other and complete each other's. I'm rather surprised that I think a lot of this work. I usually don't think much of violence for the sake of violence. But as the years piled up on my shoulders I came to realise that there are a lot of things one does not really like but many of them are just like the weather, whether or not you like it, it's just part of reality and you've got to sail with it. So it's fair for movie makers to serve it. Again, about violence I don't think any era, locality, or human group has a particular claim on it. It's always been part of our lot. Sometimes we are violent for a cause, sometimes because we don't have a cause and at other times it just same to happen. In Deliverance it seemed to have happen as a kind of claim - when some of our four protagonists inadvertently find themselves in someone else "feudal territory"... and there are people who are wishing for the day they can become an all mighty "land lord". Deliverance delivers it in a unique way and fairly unique surrounding too. If you've never seen it enjoy or suffer the ride. As for me it was the second or third time around I was looking for the tit bits I might have missed the time before, although I had a rather faint memory of it, like there were going things to happen along this river, and was that banjo player going to jump out of the screen later on...? This time I really enjoyed it and hope it'll be the same for you

reviews.review_title: A great look at how an seemingly innocent trip can show you who you really are.
reviews.content:
This movie was made before I was born, and it still stands the test of time.
The four companions, each as different as their work, take a trip down a river that is about to be used to turn a valley into a giant lake.  The plan is to conquer the river, to ride it to the bottom, and they are prepared. However, the one element that is unplanned for, that can't be planned for, is the human element.The acting in it is superb, every single character within the movie is completely and utterly believable.  The cinemetography is also great, the scenery is captured and used to help convey the story.  From the time travelling down the calm part of the river where there is no dialogue, to where the very disturbing rape scene occurs, and even towards the end of the movie where Voight has to climb the cliff to find their attackers at the middle of the rapids.That all being said, the most important aspect of the film is the story itslef.  I saw it as a tale of four friends who believe themselves to be a certain way, but are not really sure of themselves until after they are tested.Reynolds makes a statement to Voight early on in the film, that a man does not know what he's made of until he's taking aim. (While referring to hunting a deer).  That little bit of foreshadowing is evident at the end, where John Voight has a clear shot of a man who will no doubt kill them given the opportunity.  Even knowing that he raped Ned Beatty's character and would no doubtedly rape him as well (and presumably kill them both), shot thier friend Ronny Cox's character, he still could not commit murder until absolutely forced.Reynolds comes off as a very strong character, and he maintains that through the film - despite a shattered leg.  Cox is a very light hearted man who has a family and is presumably looked upon as a solid provider, yet when faced with trouble he crumbles to near madness.  Beatty is a somewhat cocky and arrogant person, but when his test comes he withdrawls into himself, and comes out stronger than before.  Voight is the everyman, arrogant rarely and looking inwards at himself.  He also rises to the occasion and even afterwards does not sit well with him.  His nightmares at the end of the movie seem not to be of the man they killed being discovered, but of the friend who did not make it back reaching out to return.I thought the movie was very full of symbolism, and is a "Must See" for anyone who enjoys some substance in thier films, instead of nothing but technological advances.

This is a very interesting horror movie. The rape scene is notorious, and will never be forgotten, but there is so much beautiful nature and excitement in this wonderful movie, that it also has that element to offer. It is amazing that a movie without supernatural elements can actually be a horror movie, but I should think that it is, because it involves so much fear.

reviews.review_title: IF you aren't rating this a "10" you have no business rating movies.
reviews.content: This is a cult classic and for good reason. I don't know one thing that can be improved on with this ealy 70's gem. They don't make movies like this anymore and I'm glad to have watched this more than once. It truly holds up. Now in 2022 just as it did 50 YEARS AGO.

reviews.review_title: I did NOT like it; I'm not sure what the point was supposed to be...
reviews.content: A woman commented that she did not know any guys who did not like this movie. I didn't. Besides being disturbing on many levels, I am not entirely sure what the point of it was, other than reinforcing negative stereotypes of the South in general and mountain men in particular. IF that was it, it succeeded admirably. I have only watched it once. That was quite enough. I would rather watch "Fail Safe" or "Testament" or "The Day After" again (and I am not crazy about watching any of the three preceding again)...Again, I am not a fan of this flick...

reviews.review_title: A Strange Film that Leaves Questions to Be Asked
reviews.content: One of the things that makes this movie unique is the ambiguous nature of the plot. A few of the events occur in a way that leaves you unsure of what has really happened. For example, we are never positive on what led to Drew's strange behavior while on the canoe and his subsequent death. One of the men says that he saw the toothless man up on the hill, but none of the other men saw him and no gunshot was heard. When they find Drew's body, there is no clear gunshot wound. Another example is when Ed shoots the man with his bow, assuming that it was the same toothless man they had encountered the day before. When he looks at the man's face he is unsure whether it is the same man, and Bobby also expresses that he is uncertain as to whom Ed had killed.I liked that there were some elements of the film that were left open-ended. The surviving characters never achieve any closure, and still live in fear that someone will find out what truly happened that weekend.

reviews.review_title: four friends from the city go on a whitewater rafting trip,and get more than they bargained for
reviews.content: even though this movie came out in 1972,it still stands up well,in my opinion.the acting is outstanding here and the changes the four main characters go through feel genuine.the movie has one very disturbing sequence and it's not so much what you see(the film is not really graphic compared to today's standards),but it's more what you hear and your mind fills in the rest.compared to similar films today,this one is rather tame.it doesn't overdo it on gore or blood and guts.it relies on suspense and tension to keep the story going.i myself prefer that approach(though I have also enjoyed the blood and guts spectacle of some film,but on a different level.for me,deliverance is a 7/10.

Yes this year is the 50th anniversary of this violent film and it still packs its punches. All i remember from what i saw at a local Drive In where my Dad took my after i bugged him to take me,is the canoeing. When the infamous mountain man scene happened my Dad threw me in the back seat and wouldn't let me see what was happening. I was 10 at the time. When i finally saw the whole film years later i saw what the fuss was about. Still a strong movie.

A great survival movie, although not necessarily "fun" to watch. Basically, a group of four friends visit a backwater area of Georgia to go canoeing down a whitewater river. The acting in this movie is phenomenal; all four of the main character actors either had great careers to start with or went on to become big; it shows. The tone of this movie is very realistic; the dialogue and the pacing and the plot all feel like things you could actually hear and see. The movie is deeply uncomfortable throughout the whole thing, but especially the "squeal like a pig" moment. I didn't enjoy that part in the movie. It wasn't badly acted or set up, it's just something I'd rather not see. There was also a bit of odd day-for-night editing/filming at the cliff-climbing scene that looked bad; otherwise the cinematography was great. Overall, a good adventure story, though not one I'd like to re-watch.

I give Deliverance the full ten points because it does what it does so well - it disturbs the bejeebers out of you!  There are not many films that give me an emotional reaction as strong as Deliverance.  Credit to Director John Boorman, Burt Reynolds, and the supporting cast. The hillbilly music score did an extremely fine job of SUBTLY taking the viewer through the various emotional states Boorman was shooting for.  Check out my complete on-line review at External Reviews on imdb.

reviews.review_title: A Lighthearted Fun Romp With Georgia's Finest People
reviews.content: Deliverance not only stood the test of time, but it conquered it, and with a good restoration that is much needed (come on Criterion!) this film easily earns its title as a classic movie. It's a disturbing and anxiety ridden survival adventure story, filled with excitement and horror, a movie that will linger in the minds of viewers for as long as this film has been around. It's truly sensational when a film that's in it's fifth decade can still form a lasting, haunting impact on the audience, showing man facing the horrors of nature, themselves, and deconstructed masculinity, Deliverance opened the door for many writers and filmmakers to explore these traits and environments, but none can match the evocative atmospheric intensity as Deliverance.

It is Burt Reynolds's best film.Based on a genre drawn from Dostoyevsky's "crime and punishment" and Edgar Allan Poe's "Tell Tale Heart" etc., the film brilliantly tackles the reality of murder and its moral/conscience consequences.It is enthralling, suspenseful and has excellent character development. Although Jon Voight had the lead role, it was Burt that delivered the best lines and more memorable performance.Recommend it highly, especially for that tune.

reviews.review_title: Brilliant film; one that really makes you think and question the world we live in!
reviews.content: This film traces the adventures of four men on a canoeing trip, which soon turns into the trip from hell when they run into a spot of trouble, which escalates out of control! This is one of the most ambiguous movies I've ever seen because it seems as if the director intentionally leaves a lot of questions unanswered. I guess that is the beauty of the film though, that we're right there with them; seeing everything through their eyes. We know as much (or as little) as they do and therefore never really learn the truth about anything.We never really discover whether their actions in this movie were right or wrong but that's the whole point, the question of whether they deserve 'deliverance' from their sins is left open for the characters in the film and us, the viewers, to ponder and decide.I don't want to give too much away but this is a film that deals with serious thought-provoking issues including rape, murder, death, sins, the law and morality and really lays such important issues down and questions them. It's an raw and intense roller-coaster and I can definitely see where films like 'Wrong Turn' got their influence from.This movie is an absolute must-see, it's gritty, realistic and intense and shows just how easily sheer bliss can turn into sheer hell whilst questioning morality, conscience, human nature and the society we live in along the way.

reviews.review_title: Think it can't happen? Try again.
reviews.content: After having my own backwoods nightmare, I was interested in renting this one after a friend made a remote parallel to this movie upon hearing about my experience.Think it can't happen? I trajected off of I-95 in Maryland one night recently to avoid the Susquahanna River toll and to use the opportunity to fill up the car at a place where gas is cheap. In the town of Conowingo, I encountered an aggressive driver and wound up involved in a major incident of road rage. I was stalked and harassed but managed to make it to a convenient store and stop within a reasonable amount of time. The driver got out of his car, was threatening and virulent, and approached me. I called the police on my cell phone. The other person involved was so hostile that I couldn't get out of my car and had to spray pepper spray out of a halfway open window.After a few minutes, the guy pulled his car to another side of the store. Things calmed down, and I went into the store to grab a Coke while I waited for the police. Right as I got finished being rung up, the cashier said to another co-worker "Here come the calvary". Apparently, everyone in the store knew what was going on.I'm the one who called the cops, but the entire situation turned on me. Another group of people that weren't even involved told the cops that I was driving like a maniac, came up and pointed me out saying "This is the crazy guy". I had no idea who these people were. It appeared that some of the townsfolk collaborated and ganged up on me. As I stood there dressed preppy next to my Toyota Camry looking and feeling like an obvious target, the cops searched my car and even asked if I had been drinking. I was even asked to recite the "ABCs" and count backwards from 59 to 36. Given I had several groups of people mentioning that I was driving insanely, the cop had no choice but to react that way. However, these idiot rednecks had a number of fallacies in their story that undermined their credibility including telling the cops I had a gun. So, fortunately, the cops were rationale enough to realize that their story was fabricated upon finding no gun. They let me go, and I consider myself very lucky. Fortunately, it was state police; things might not have gone so well if it were local law enforcement.My experience heightened the realism that this movie successfully projects. This is one you should not pass up, and if you ever go off the trail, beware!

If this isn´t one of the best films ever made than I don´t know what a good film is. Forget all the rip-offs, this is the one. Although being nearly 30 years old, it dosen´t show. It´s one of the few timeless films that will last forever.

reviews.review_title: My grainy VHS, I need to upgrade!
reviews.content: Four city guys take a canoe trip in remote Georgia but find themselves in danger not just from the river itself but also from the local inbred rednecks. I think that Deliverance is quite possibly the original backwoods survival horror/action thriller, many more were to follow, often in the form as slasher movies. This movie is famous for two scenes in particular, firstly the duelling banjos at the beginning, then the notorious male rape "squeal like a pig" scene. The banjo duel is fantastic, only thing I felt that was that having one of the best parts right at the start set the bar too high for the remainder. Burt Reynolds is great as the macho leader of the group and the actors did their own impressive white water rapids stunts. I'm scoring this 7/10 because I felt that the film was a little too long, I found the last part rather slow, and I watched it on VHS, given a better quality print I would most likely have scored it higher. Oh yes, and the toothless hillbillies really looked the part, very unnerving!

reviews.review_title: This is a very good movie
reviews.content: This is a very good movie that is much more than the simple outdoor adventure genre. It´s more than just an action film and the group of adventurers have more to deal with than the forces of nature. It definitely is an ageless gem that is just as good today as it was in 1972.This is an excellent film folks.

reviews.review_title: What A Fine Day For A Trip Down The Cahulawassee River
reviews.content: As I understand it - (According to those elite, high'n'mighty "snobs-of-cinema") - Deliverance ranks right up there as being a true treasure of American film-making from the early 1970's.And, if one does dare to speak out disrespectfully of this much-lauded cinematic treasure they are automatically labelled by those "snobs" as being an oaf and a despicable heathen for doing so.With all of the macho-man "ball-scratching" that takes place in this ultimate "buddy" picture (especially from the likes of Burt Reynolds) - I guess that I can (sort of) understand why this film is so highly praised and endlessly revered (even to this very day, nearly 50 years later).But, if you ask me - Deliverance has got to be yet another one of those utterly inferior, puzzling, and over-rated pictures that is repeatedly defended to the death by those "self-righteous snobs" who still choose to view it through the guise of rose-coloured glasses.

I've heard from many people that this film is an absolute classic, and in many ways I would agree.It holds up well with snappy dialogue, great performances from the four main actors, and brilliant direction and cinematography in a beautiful natural setting.The story of four city boys from Atlanta setting off to canoe down a River, before a dam floods a valley...is a simple idea, but the tension is built really well as soon as they meet some of the locals, who are played off as rather dim witted and almost sinister.There is an incident with some locals, half way through the film at which point the protagonists situation becomes quite hazardous...however instead of amping up the tension throughout the remainder of the film, it does sort of flatten off a little bit...which is a shame.This is the template for a lot of similarly themed thriller / horror movies, and worth a watch!

reviews.review_title: Deliver me from the stresses of modern life
reviews.content: Absolute must see for fans of thriller adventures wow. Beautiful photography/cinematography, simply breathtaking. Boorman manages the movie with a solid pace. Great acting all around, I think some people dislike certain characters and tend to pass them off as bad actors. Ned Beatty (in his first role?!) did amazing, Ronny cox played the sniveling do gooder part well, Burt Reynolds's in his breakout role is the spitting image of STERLING ARCHER himself, and this might be Jon Voights best movie. He was simply great.Nothing about this movie seems fake. Although old, all the stunts and everything were done by the actors and with minimal safety involved. So major props to them. I was told Jon voight actually climbed that cliff! My only gripe is the filter they put over the shots where he is climbing the cliff to make it appear like night. I get that was a common technique in the early 70's but it's just not appealing to the eyes. Certain plot points might leave you wondering what just happened? But all in all this was a high 7/low 8. I really enjoyed it.

reviews.review_title: A Potent Portrait Of Man In Extremis. Highly Recommended.
reviews.content: A potent film. Four characters are developed, subtly and succinctly, and then, just as deftly, pushed over the edge. They set out to experience the wilderness of the Cahulawassee River and find it both wonderful and dangerously wild.Patient cinematography captures the river's beauty, isolation, and, later, its ominous force. Crisp, unhurried, often stationary shots let the Cahulawassee's rapids speak for themselves, but equally let the threat of the river's silent stretches resonate.The burbling, roaring, quiet water is this film's soundtrack. This lack, by and large, of extra-diagetic music perfectly suits the material; the audience never gets to experience everyday movieland. The one exception to this rule is the 'Duelling Banjos' theme, which, while initially forming part of the story, later echoes down the river to great effect.The song, as first exchanged between one of the canoers and an autistic hillbilly, is a deservedly famous showstopper. However, this film is far more than a song.The thrill and terror of exploration; the disappearance of wilderness; the light and dark sides of both nature and man; loyalty; faith in others and in society; democracy; the morality of killing; the clash of urban and rural culture; prejudice; notions of justice; the capacities of man in extremis; the consequences of secrecy; man 'after the fall'  this film touches upon many complex and powerful themes, yet this richness is rarely conspicuous and never belaboured.Performances are universally excellent. John Voight's understated showing hypnotises: looking into to his eyes we experience the film's trials, and on the other side we feel changed as he feels changed. Burt Reynolds and Ned Beatty are also convincing in their more exuberant roles. The secondary characters that populate Deliverance strikingly transport the film to the edge of civilisation. The lingering peep-show shots of Lewis's search for a driver are a disturbing portent.Highly Recommended.

In the late 60s and early 70s there was a rise in dark and gritty cinema tackling the grim subject matter and themes and did not pull their punches. The 1972 John Boorman film Deliverance was one of them, a horrifically interesting film.Four friends, Lewis (Burt Reynolds), Ed (Jon Voight), Bobby (Ned Beatty) and Drew (Ronny Cox) go to the remote wilderness of the Deep South to canoe down the Cahulawassee River before it flooded by the construction of a dam. But in the sticks the men meet very hostile hillbillies, leading to a horrific sexual assault and all four men to explore their dark sides.Deliverance is a very atmospheric film and it is done by the simplicity of Boorman's direction. He uses plenty of long shots and single takes, letting the power of the acting do the talking. Music is kept to a minimum and it adds to the atmosphere as most of the sounds we hear are nature, making you feel like you are in wild forest and it added to the horror when we see the infamous rape scene. It gave the moment even more power.Deliverance has an great cast and all four lead actors give excellent performances as they play some difficult roles and situations. Lewis is a macho man, a survivalist who is the most independently minded and the man who shares the hillbilly view of independent and love of wildness of the area. Ed is someone who ends up having to explore his dark side during their journey and Drew tries to be the conscience and rational of the group. All four end up having a dark bound, knowing what happened in the woods and their relationship had a very Stephen King esque feel to it.Deliverance was made in the early 70s, a time where hostility to the Vietnam War was high but it was unpopular in American culture to criticise it in film or books. Like a lot of good storytelling a story can be used as a way to subvertly talk about a subject through a different and you can see the Vietnam parallels in this film. The group of men are city men who suffer a culture crash and hostility from the locals, going into a hot forest area with an enemy around them as they try to survive in an onslaught and the war atrocities before the suffering the aftermath on the home front.Added to the Vietnam theme there are themes of manhood, the dark side of human nature that inhabits men, especially when they are alone in the woods and far away from civilisation and even a look at the nature of these communities who isolated and hostile to authority. But the film does have a surreal look to the hill folk with all their deformities and go through the old clichés that everyone in the rural Deep South is inbred. Finally there is even a slight environmental message about the destruction of the dam would course to the valley.Deliverance is an interesting film that was well paced and the dark nature was clearly following the hallmarks of cinema for the period. It is certainly worthy viewing.

reviews.review_title: A creepy reminder of the ugly side of life.
reviews.content: One of the reasons the 1970s are considered to be the best era of filmmaking.  This gritty, suspense remains Burt Reynolds' finest moment as an actor and puts an idellible mark on any male's psyche. I first saw this in the mid-70s on Cable when I was about 11 or 12 years old while living in south Florida.  Needless to say, I never ever went camping or canoeing anywhere off the beaten path. Having seen the movie countless times now as an adult, it still registers a creepy impact. The ugly side of life and the human condition can be just around any corner, anywhere, whether in the concrete jungles of cities or in the seemingly tranquil beauty of nature. Chilling and unforgettable.

reviews.review_title: One of the finest films ever
reviews.content: Deliverance is, in my opinion, one of the finest movies ever made. Several other reviewers have passed comments like 'boring', Obviously subscribers to the brain dead, 2 minute attention span, machine gun edited film school of (much of) modern cinema. Oh dear!Many other reviewers have passed comments like, "for the 70's, an excellent film.." Err.., hang on a minute, the 1970s was probably the finest era of Hollywood cinema!! An era when there were; numerous, super talented leading actors who were noted for their ACTING rather than their looks, great directors, and interesting plots - coupled with a coming of age of cinematography and film/camera techniques. The 70's was an era when so many topics (war, love, crime, drama) were made into true classic, gripping must-see movies.Oh HOW I wish the same could be said today!! Getting back to Deliverance! I won't talk about the plot, as other reviews here talk in depth about that. I will simply say that this is one of the afore mentioned 'must-see' movies!! The acting throughout (by the leads and the support - many of whom were genuine locals) is extraordinary. Burt Reynolds in particular blew me away, simply because I never realised (when I first saw it) that he could be so utterly brilliant as an 'straight' actor - rather than a comedic actor. The cinematography is jaw dropping, and the editing is seamless (so unlike today movies today)- slow and relaxed in parts (allowing the film to 'breath') and tight and fast when needed.The sheer beauty of the photography is a joy, and the wonderful scenery and beautiful surroundings belie the horrible situation the four central characters find themselves in.Like all great movies, the movie contains COMPELLING sequences and in Deliverance there are two of note - 1) the dualling banjos scene, and 2) the infamous rape scene. Like the Russian Roulette scene in the Deer Hunter, or the 'Is it safe' dental torture scene in Marathon man - these scenes are utterly gripping, so brilliantly acted and believable, you cannot divert your attention from the screen. Such moments pass into movie legend. Such scenes are full of human drama - a drama that is intensified by the ACTING - and not ruined (as is often the case today) by needless, superfluous fast and rapid editing. The camera is allowed to dwell on actors faces, or actors as a group - so that the interaction is more realistic, and the movie watcher feels more like an 'observer' (instead of just being made to feel dizzy and sick - as is often the case with the over the top editing typical today!) I am 32, and how I envy the cinemagoer of the 70's. Thank god for DVD! The only down side of this movie is the negative image it portrays of the 'South'. I have seen several documentaries of life in the south, and have visited Georgia and the Carolinas. The majority of people I met (and observed on the documentaries) from the region are very friendly and helpful. For many 'southerners', two truths pervade, religion and poverty. Life is very, very tough for many of the people in these regions and they are suitably hardy and phlegmatic about life's struggles and death. There is a gritty and raw side to their character.I have travelled widely throughout the US, and the many of the people of the North Eastern US have not got a clue about life in the South.I don't want to get political, but George Bush Jnr could do with addressing some REAL social concerns (i.e. poverty) in his own country before 'preaching' to the wider world about 'democracy' and 'freedom'.The movie Deliverance portrays the poverty and hardship of the South (that still exists today) accurately, but it gives a disproportionate image of the 'evil' side of the region. Having said that - it is a story!!

reviews.review_title: Extremely overrated and boring!! Another movie that's dated and overrated!!
reviews.content: Burt Reynolds was surprisingly decent in this film but its extremely overrated. A 7.7 REALLY, it has a horrible negative rape scene and then we get a whimpy pay back. The end is ok but extremely predictable. Have no idea why this is rated so high, its probably the old 1 says it's great so everyone follows so they dont look stupid. In reality you look stupid for saying great film, it's a VERY basic movie with basic acting performances. Watch taken, or murder in the first or green mile skip this bore ass overrated film.

reviews.review_title: That creepy banjo loop will stay stuck in your head for days after
reviews.content: It felt weird finally watching this film I'd heard so much about it over the years and seen so many references to it that it felt like I'd already seen it. The pacing and built up anticipation of this film is awesome, I'd almost put it right up there with the shining. You constantly get the feeling that something terrible is going to happen. At the time it was released it must have shocked audiences as its pretty extreme for back then but nothing as graphic as we have now. I kind of like that about it though because it sticks to the classic form of horrors while mixing it with a newer more extreme style. Its also it's realistic quality that makes it particularly scary, it feels as if it could happen to anyone. It was strange to see Jon Voight and Burt Reynolds so young they're both almost unrecognisable from how they look now. I really liked the way the camera stopped and focused on people's faces and expressions throughout the film making them even more creepy. The people in the town at the end were just as strange as those by the river. With the title being 'deliverance' it was clever the way they got out of the river by the church. The only thing I didn't like about this film was the ending. It kept you feeling like something more was going to happen but it just cut out with him waking up from a bad dream. All in all it's a thrilling watch but may be a bit slow for people use to watching more modern horrors/thrillers.

Deliverance is a thrilling and disturbing survival film set in a beautiful wilderness. A group of friends can hardly travel into backwoods without someone making a reference to this movie. As fun as Dueling Banjos is to listen to, you'll never hear it quite the same after watching this movie. For the most part, it's the battle against the river and its ranging rapids that deliver the action and suspense. But the most memorable scene turns this movie into a full fledge horror film. This scene, involuing rape, is disturbing
and you'll probably wish you could unsee it. It went too far for me, but it no doubt set a certain darker tone that made the whole movie more ominous. It displays the lawlessness and depravity of these hillbillies which amps up the film's fear factor. But, this scene will no doubt keep this movie off the watchlist for many, and I don't blame them. It's not
for the faint of heart.Otherwise, Burt Reynolds and Jon Voight take turns
leading us through this story with impressive
performances. The banter between the men is realistic
and entertaining. As the movie says, "You can't beat
nature." All you can do is experience and survive it. Perhaps what makes this movie as creepy as it is, is
that the events aren't over the top or unrealistic. Everything that happens feels a little too possible.

Going backwards, many fans of Burt Reynolds happened upon DELIVERANCE later on, and the one big difference between that and even his better-than-car-chase movies is it's an ensemble of four characters who get almost equal story-time and importance to the plot...A would-be vacationing adventure of city men taking to the white water rapids, led by a confident and gusty survivalist-type Reynolds as Lewis, good friend of polar opposite Jon Voight, the actual main character, who, as Ed, can hardly sling a bow-and-arrow while Burt leads one of the all-time great bow-and-arrow rescues...And that's after what DELIVERANCE is known for... the term "Squeal like a pig" began here, from a hillybilly-to-city-slicker rape sequence against the miraculously first-time actor Ned Beatty by Bill McKinney, who utters the now-iconic phrase during the most bizarre, nightmarish and daringly exploitative cult-cinema scene ever...Followed by a proverbial woodsy "courtroom" argument, combining law and philosophy, that proves Reynolds was a greater semi-young, clean-shaven actor than middle-aged, mustached movie-star...After which the best parts follow the weakest in which a solo Jon Voight goes after the second of the two hicks, shifting from offensive coward to defensive killer: his edgy performance is smoother than the surprisingly shoddy, too-dark cinematography in a night scene lasting too long...Ironically leaving some of the best scenes AFTER the white water adventure... as director John Boorman's intrepid, brutally daring action flick becomes a slow-burn thriller when, while in the connected small town, Voight and Beatty hide a secret as powerfully subtle as that aforementioned heated argument between group pacifist Ronny Cox (the guitar part of the famous dueling banjos) and the man who'd do no better... Burt Reynolds, just getting started.

reviews.review_title: Okay, But I Did Not Enjoy It As Most Others
reviews.content: I would say that I liked this movie, but there is no way I could say it was anything overly great. It is definitely suspenseful, there is no doubt about that. The problem that I had with it was that I spent most of the second half of the movie yelling at the characters to take other, more rational, more obvious actions than the ones that they were taking. It was as if I was watching a cheesy horror movie and the group was about to split up rather than stay together. Also, I was not overly impressed with any characters or performances. They were good, but nothing special. The plot was good enough. The situation was interesting and definitely kept me interested. As I said before, the suspense factor could not have been better, but the movie as a whole could have. The beginning of this film showed a lot of promise and even throughout the end kept me interested, but it was lacking something for me to think anything beyond a "pretty good" rating for "Deliverance". Oh, and of course, the dueling banjos scene was terrific.

Deliverance is indisputably one of the greatest films ever.  I can think of very few others that have incited such a strong reaction from me in terms of emotional state - Breaking the Waves is the only film I've seen that can rival it in this way.The acting is flawless, with fine stars who seem to have fallen into obscurity now.  Aside from the main players, the 'mountain men' are amongst the most sinister villains in film history, and the banjo playing boy is coldly sinister in two of the best moments.As always the infamous rape scene must be mentioned.  In short, it is horrible.  Not for the immature, nor those seeking entertainment and nothing else.  Deliverance demands to be watched.  Those who consider themselves film fans must do so.  I hope it will be remembered with Taxi Driver as one of the best films to come out of the 1970s.

Four city boys, let's call 'em Macho (Burt Reynolds), Piggy (Ned Beatty), Wannabe (Jon Voight) and Banjo (Ronny Cox), go out in the wild to do some kayaking before a power dam dries up the mighty river.On their way they meets some redneck yokels, who as degenerate they are, who bring up some troubles on their way and soon Piggy notices, that some one has stuck something up his bowl, while Wannabe was tied on a tree. But just before Wannabe gets something lodged in his throat Macho shoots one of the rednecks with his trusty bow.Together the city slickers decide, that they bury the cadaver and try to get away with as little ruckus as possible. But as it happens the Toothfairy, the surviving yokel, decides to put some obstacles on their way, in form of bullets.'Deliverance' is often said to be a manly film and that is what it is. Four men battling against the nature, getting acquainted with their wild manly sides. But we also learn, that in the end even Macho cries, when he's hurt and Wannabes can safe the day.The film is what it is, a product of 70's, nihilistic view of a man in the nature and how he copes from difficulties. but the film also has some memorable scenes it, even though the way it portrays the redneck Americans is far from pretty.What happens in the kayaking trip, stays in the kayaking trip.

I thought I would include spoilers in here just so I can use the word "Spoilerance" as my title, so read with caution.I felt that this was a cutting edge film and I was amazed by the fact that the actors did their own stunts and were not insured due to budget constraints.  As Lewis Medlock teases 'what's the point to having insurance...there's no risk.'  This even accentuates the authenticity of the story.This story has two underlying themes: a moral one and one concerning urbanisation.  It shows what can happen to normal, moral-minded folk when pressed to the limit of survival.  A weekend away in the wild might bring out the worst in people.  No one is innocent.  This was happening during the cradle of globalisation.  The last of the untouched and obscure country ready to be consumed.  As I was only three years old when the movie came out, I have been looking for that lost obscurity ever since.  No mystery is left.  As Lewis Medlock mentions that we have sold off this Eden for our own cushy lifestyles.  We greedily want both worlds.  We want the comfort of our own homes and families and jobs but still want to escape and fish in the final frontier which we will rapidly flood our development on.  Because of the enemy of modernisation, the natural world that we are destroying is demonstrated by the "hillbillies", who wreak their proverbial revenge upon us. This is an analogy of an inevitable cause and effect relationship between the wild and urbanisation.Since this is closely based on the book, it is difficult to determine what is a spoiler and what is not.  I read the book and saw the film twice and think that it's pretty close and no wonder since the author appears in it himself.  The only difference worth noting is that Ed Gentry props himself down in between rocks rather than up in a tree.  He is below his mountain man rather than above.  Makes it a bit scarier.  My favourite part is when Ed Gentry falls from the snapped rope and lands embracing the stiff in the water accompanied by the Seventies psychedelic soundtrack appropo for the time.A typical weekend out with the boys: One guy gets raped, one gets killed and two get injured and have to cover up for their crimes in the face of their caregivers.It should have been called Up Your Creek Without a Paddle.  I would say it's in my top ten list.  Beautiful scenery!

"Deliverance," seems to me, to be a movie that audiences and critics may surely avoid today, based on that scene. Yes, that scene I'm talking about where Bobby (Ned Beatty) is forced to strip down to his underwear, and shortly after, is raped by a snarling, toothless hillbilly who seeks to dominate the cowering and frightened city man ("I'm gonna make you squeal like a pig. Weeeeeeeeee!"). This scene and others like it make up one of the most disturbing films about human brutality ever captured on celluloid. The plot: four Atlanta businessmen (Burt Reynolds, Jon Voight, Ronny Cox, and the aforementioned Beatty) take a canoing trip on the Appalachian river. Things get ugly when that scene rolls around, when the four men encounter two bloodthirsty backwoodsmen, and it quickly evolves into an experience none of the men will ever forget. It's a daring feat that John Boorman (who followed this up with the superior 1981 fantasy adventure, "Excalibur") was at the helm of this violent, disturbing thriller that dives deep into what makes man the way he is, and in detailing the line where civilization ends, and "reality" begins. Boorman's film, adapted from James Dickey's novel of the same title, is savage and definitely not for the faint-of-heart.8/10

Deliverance created some serious controversy upon its release by featuring an "intense" homosexual rape scene. Four friends decide to go out kayaking in Redneckland, Mississippi. Unfortunately, their day plans are ruined as they are met with some uninvited hillbilly company. The premise of the movie is excellent, however, things went wrong. The duration of the film is too long and drawn out. A few of the four kayaking buddies are so annoying that you don't gravitate towards them at all. Making supposedly "intense" sense highly unremarkable. I don't really know how much controversy this movie stirred when it came out, I just made that up. But if you've heard good things about this movie, someone was making that up as well. I would recommend this movie to people that don't mind long, uneventful films.

This movie is the tale of friends who go on a wilderness trip that goes awry, Featuring a strapping Burt Reynolds, John Voight, and Ned Beatty, these guys endure one heck of an adventure.The character arc of Beatty in particular is worth mentioning, as he starts out a bumble guy hanging out with his buddies and then finds himself in the throws of passion with an Appalachian man with a fondness for pork. If there was ever a hillbilly 50 Shades of Gray, it's this film.

reviews.review_title: You done took a wrong turn. This river don't go to AINTREE.
reviews.content: I am a member of a canoeing club and I can tell you the truth that Deliverance is synonomous with the peacefulness and tranquility of the experience. As we put our boats into the water, banjoes echo in the back of the conscious mind. This movie is timeless because it waxes philosophical of human's place in nature and technology's effect upon man's relationship with nature. We see it in the bow fishing. We see it in the home made tent. There is also city man's disdain and feeling of superiority to the rural woodsman "cracker". The fact that the Banker from Atlanta (Ned Beatty) has "bad teeth" is meant to put him on the same level with the woodsmen who also have bad teeth. Ultimately, the struggle of life and death supersedes "civilized man's" suppositives about "The Law". This canoe trip ends too soon for the viewer, but alas Not Soon Enough for the characters.

reviews.review_title: One of the Great Guy Films
reviews.content: Of course the "meaning" is crystal clear - the difference between "civilization" - the world of golf, suburban homes and air conditioning - and the wild, where the only law is survival of the fittest, can be paper thin, and these 4 yuppies crossed the line.  The great irony is that these city boys get nailed by the wilderness that their brethren are about to erradicate.  The movie is one of the great icons of the last 30 years - jam packed with chilling moments, funny bits of guy talk, as well as campy scenes and dialogue.  I think the film making is in fact remarkable - the cast was on their own on the river (get the dvd for details); some beautiful scenery was captured as backdrop, and eventually we go along on a Disney ride gone wrong - a hair-raising adventure.  Burt Reynolds, playing Lewis, by far the most intriguing character, peaked in this film; the rest of his career unfortunately has been pretty much exploitation (well, till Boogie Nights).  The other three obviously each have had sterling careers and are terrific together.  This is a bona fide classic, a must-see.

reviews.review_title: One of the great American movies, one of the great movies ABOUT America.
reviews.content: This is one of the best movies in history. What's it about? It's about 4 guys from the city on a weekend camping/rafting trip. It's about the war in Vietnam. It's about the settling of the nation. It's about the entire American experience. Aeschylus could have written the spare story. No character is shown who does not have to be there. What happens in this deceptively simple movie is so wide open as to carry the weight of any American theme you can name. Any human theme. It can stand with Citizen Kane, Blow-up, On the Waterfront, The Bicycle Thief, the best of Buster Keaton, Howard Hawks'best. Like that. And it's also about limitations, human limits, the limits of civilized power and the power to civilized, the limits of law and order, the limitations of justice, the limitations of revenge, and the limitations of what we call masculinity. How can you tell it's not just an action/adventure movie? Because the SCENE is not the end of it (and the SCENE's resolution). Deliverance is so much more than THE SCENE. Everything begins closing in after that SCENE. Nothing is delivered. No one is delivered. The film ends. It has to. But the story and characters keep going without the benefit of being on celluloid. It keeps going in the minds of anyone who sees it. Deliverance deserves books written about it. And a hundred books wouldn't be enough.4 guys go into northern Georgia for a weekend. They encounter what they perceive as the Other. But after the first encounter, things keep haunting them, physically and emotionally. There is true non-supernatural horror. There is death. Murder? Justifiable? Unknown. Or rather, open to debate. There is more death. Characters are broken in mind and spirit and body. An entire American community is seen dying, down to graves and churches and ... what constitutes a community. This is not a fun rollercoaster ride because so much matters and we care about the leads and we care about ourselves yet the ride never ends...how could it? The story is constructed that way. We see actions we might normally applaud but those actions have the consequences of real life and the consequences that other people bring to the story; the 4 leads are not safe from the reality of other people and THEIR stubborn insistence on their own lives and actions as human beings with their own agency.And the plot can be summed up in 2 or 3 sentences.And it is a horror movie. Never doubt that. The director of the first Stephen King adaptation lifted his final scene from the final scene of Deliverance. The so-called perky theme is played by ghosts over the end credits, faint, hard to hear, and echo-ey. Get Out also contains an old-timey song, and it is played exactly the same way and is no longer perky or upbeat. A Clockwork Orange features an old upbeat song, but it is sung by the leader of a teenaged gang as he rapes a woman and assaults her husband.Deliverance is horror that never ends. No one has clean hands, not even the vocal proponent of right and wrong. Not even him.No one learns, no one triumphs. There is only living day to day in a world filled with horror for everyone. There might be intermittent moments of peace and beauty and maybe even feeling a connection to another person but it's soon back to the horror.

Deliverance is mixture of drama and horror. The film manages to show how a group of ordinary men who are just taking are short break can get wound up in such meaningless acts of terror. The first half hour of Deliverance is like watching a different film to the one that comes out latter. The first scenes show these normal men just having a good time and some beautiful imagery of the American land that surrounds them. The scenes after this are very different, the film all of a sudden turns out to be very dark and asks the viewer "What would would you do in this situation?" This is disturbing and shows just how when people are not around the cops become cruel and meaningless. This all leads up to showing how human nature can be so evil when left to it's bitter beginning.The film is definitely not one of entertainment value and is a film a film to be studied and thought about long after the chilling and depressing closing credits. What makes the film so depressing is that the action that causes everything to kick off is meaningless and so immoral that it is heart wrenching. You also feel as though the film is teasing you with the purposely inappropriate banjo music as the soundtrack. Deliverance is very different to most films, it's not afraid to put the viewer through such tense and nail-biting situations. Not only is the film disturbing, it is also very sad. It shows how a group of innocent men's lives are changed from something so pointless and pitiless. The atmosphere creates a real feeling of menace and lurking evil.Through all this the film is one amazingly harrowing experience and really does make you think about the ideas of how men can change when put through life and death situations. The men's stress makes them turn into something different to their normal self's, they have to become almost in-human to defeat the threatening evil that hangs over them like a shadow. Every single one of these men's lives are automatically altered through such a terrifying experience. You never know what's round the corner and in the end the men are fighting to survive.The acting by the cast is tremendous and Jon Voight and Burt Reynolds show very intense attitudes and you really know the kind of people they are by the end of the movie. The film is a character study, it's a real life horror movie and a great image of isolation captured on lens. The direction techniques are very precise and capture the beautiful American landscape where this terrible journey occurs. The film also perfectly displays a culture that is in isolation, most often called "hillbillies". The film for sure makes you have a real fear and loathing for the kind portrayed in the film. Of course not all of them are crazed loonies, but the film does put that attitude across. The techniques of camera shots used show the stress, anger, destruction, terror and beauty wonderfully.The scripting for the film is perfect and is filled with so many memorable scenes and imagery. The image of Burt Reybolds holding up the bow and focus on his dilated pupil, is a very cold image. Deliverance is certainly one of the best films ever made, it mixes so many techniques to create a masterpiece. Watch it now, but be prepared for something to make you think and that is very different...

Deliverance is one of those movies that makes you think twice before taking your next camping trip. What starts out as good old fashioned fun among friends, turns into a nightmare.Strong performances(3 Golden Globe Nominations) from all involved adds an element of realism to a script that already holds it's own weight. The fluid direction from legendary John Boorman moves the story along at a manageable pace, adding suspense at the perfect moments. It will keep you on the edge of your seat, or trembling in fear as the four friends battle their morals as they desperately fight for their lives.It is considered a classic by many and for very good reason. It is real, dark, dramatic, suspenseful, all interwoven into a story about friendship and their fight for survival in the wilderness. If you are looking for a must see movie before you die, this will definitely deliver.8.5/10

I expected this to be a fun adventure but it turned out to be another traumatizing experience (double feature with Murmur of the Heart wasn't a good idea). The movie dragged at the beginning and I wasn't really invested into it until that moment came and I was like what is happeningggg??? Then I loved everything after that, especially the whole cover up. Also, all of the performances are really great!

reviews.review_title: Deliverance didnt deliver what i was expecting
reviews.content: I suppose ,Deliverance at the time of release in 1972 would have been seen as one of the most violent films seen at the cinema but 30 years on it seems quite tame. I was expecting a Southern Comfort type of film only better but it didnt really happen. In fact you could say that apart from the first 45 minutes nothing really happens at all! The acting is good and the film looks good but where were the Hill Billies chasing the men? Still worth a look though. 7 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: Maybe not a "shocker" by today's standards ...
reviews.content: I've just been reading all of the comments about this movie and was interested by the different points of view of those submitting them. I have to say, first of all, that I totally agree with the person who said that you SHOULD ALSO READ THE NOVEL. Like any other story, all of the various elements within it can NEVER be transferred to the screen - novels are just too long and involved. I totally DISAGREE that Boorman did a crappy job of directing or that this film in ANY WAY stinks. The first time that I saw this is when it came out in 1972. In "judging" this picture, you need to remember that societal expectations were a LOT different (in America) than they are today. EVERYONE was talking about the "rape scene" in this movie. NO ONE had filmed something like that, that I know of - or that I remember anyone else ever having heard of being in a movie at that time. Most probably, the issue hadn't been addressed within a novel, either - until Dickie wrote this. I was 14 when I snuck in to see this - and it had an impact even though I knew what was coming. I'd read the book right after seeing it - and, again, it's MUCH more involved and dramatic. A few years ago, I took a course called "The Male In American Literature" and was surprised and pleased to find that "Deliverance" was on the syllabus as one of the stories we'd be studying. In re-reading this as an adult (and after a higher education) there were many things I had never noticed before. Dickie uses a LOT OF "foreshadowing" in the story - right down to something that no one else in the class noticed, but I did: the color orange is often associated with "caution" and he mentions it a whole lot of times. I went back and watched the movie again, as well - it had been many years since I had first seen it. I did notice what another reviewer mentions here - that you never do see the identity of that other person in the tow truck - and I mentioned to my friend that for the first time I thought it was those same guys who were involved in accosting the canoeing party further downriver. Someone else mentions here (in these reviews) about how the kid who had played "Dueling Banjoes" with Drew doesn't even acknowledge him when they are passing under him, under the bridge. Again - foreshadowing - another subtle hint that something terrible is about to happen. I don't think that this story - whether the book or the novel - is a "bad" one at all. I agree totally with the person who said that there are much deeper elements at work here. If you thought the movie stunk, read the book - then go back and give the movie another chance. You'll understand the story better and will see it in a totally different light. It is also interesting how in this story, like in Harper Lee's American classic "To Kill A Mockingbird," the author raises the question if killing another human being is ever "justified." I don't think that any of can really say, with complete conviction and assuredness, that we "never could." I sure as hell wouldn't have wanted to go through something like that canoe trip. But we all have our own "baggage" in life, don't we? All have our own stories to tell - if not about ourselves and things that have happened to us, then certainly about horrible things which have happened to someone we know. In closing, I'd just like to say that whoever compared this to "Blair Witch" ...  Well, let's just say that I think any 5-year-old could have made the latter. There's NO comparison in "literary value," so to speak. I debated asking for my money back from renting the tape. Had I spent the extra money to see it at the theater, I definitely would have walked out half way through, and would most likely have demanded my money be returned. "Deliverance" is NOT trash. The characters are VERY realistic, the story line is haunting in subtle undertones, and the acting is nothing short of EXCELLENT. Personally, I can't see how anyone would think any different of it, but we're all entitled to our opinion.

Shot in the beautiful nature this tragic story passes us. Four friends go on a canoe trip deep in the woods. On their way they have some trouble with locals and what was supposed to be a beautiful and exciting journey turns out to be a disaster.The four friends are played by Jon Voight, Burt Reynolds, Ned Beatty and Ronny Cox. They all are good in their roles, especially Burt Reynolds as the cool guy. There are some very disturbing scenes, one with Ned Beatty in particular, but they work the way they were meant. A haunting but very good story against beautiful nature, even more beautifully shot. Only the cinematography of the river and the woods is worth the watch, if you can stand the violence that does occur.

reviews.review_title: It's more than just the theme music...
reviews.content: In honor of the late Burt Reynolds' passing today, it's time to revisit some of his classic films, starting with Deliverance, you know, the movie with the famous banjo tune. Released during the new hollywood era, this film became a huge success for Warner Bros and its parent company, Warner Communications, which was formed in 1972 after former parent Kinney sold off its entertainment assets after a parking scandal.

The movie begins with four men planning to go for a trip in a ravaged river, considering the river is on borrowed time. Main characters, in a first sight, aren't anything special or remarkable from each other-- maybe with exception of Lewis, who seems to be an aggressive man. Once they enter the river, they face two local inhabitants that feel like raping them for no apparently reason-- which was probably an inspiration for Wes Craven in 77's "The Hills Have Eyes". After the raping indeed happens, lots of bad things happen to the main characters, making it hard to not feel impressed with those scenes. Most of the tension is created by the strong direction John Boorman gives us; he focuses on the character's feelings, followed by a bunch of unforeseen situations they've been into, like the leg breaking, the dangerous escalade, among others. After they talk to the police, it seems like they're all going to be caught by the cops, since they are all lying. Those scenes were also tense, and I'm very thankful they finally got away with murder in the end. "Deliverance" is one of the most tense films I've seen, and probably one of the best of the 70's. It's well worth your time, believe me!

As another reviewer noted, what makes Deliverance spooky is not specifically the plot but the plausibility of it all, and I completely agree. This film conveys being in a survival situation very well. It's correctly an ugly and unglamorous experience enhanced by the nontraditional ending and writing.Deliverance may be a disturbing watch (especially for more innocent minds) but aside from the one notorious scene it doesn't go too far. Personally I think that scene really adds to the gravity of the plot, but I can see how it would be pretty shocking to some people.As for the technical stuff, the characters are memorable and each one contributes to the story and the deeper symbolism of the film. The performances of all four lead actors, in particular Jon Voight, are top notch and deserve the praise they receive. The lack of much of a score really contributes to the suspense and plausibility I mentioned above.My only complaint is that the pacing seemed rushed/unpolished at times. They just needed to let the scenes breathe a little bit more- that would put this movie into the legendary category for me.

A master class in uncomfortable, Deliverance is a completely unique storyline that follows 4 men down the river. When they come across mountain men with no teeth, things get really bad and choices they're forced to make stretch their morality.

reviews.review_title: Reynolds is the man. Squeal like a pig!
reviews.content:
A thriller from 1972 that had escaped my viewing attention until last night but proved thought provoking and at times quite shocking.It follows in the vein of other thrillers of the era such as Straw Dogs (1971) and Last House On The Left (1972).Basically it follows four city guys who go on a 'country' trip to a fictional U.S. river, the River Chattooga that will shortly be no more because of the construction of a huge man-made dam.The four plan to canoe down the river past several rapids in glorious scenery of the river, the river banks and the woods that accompany them.The four are quite varied. Ed (Jon Voight) is quite quiet and more sensitive, the survivalist is Lewis (Burt Reynolds) the other two are Bobby (Ned Beatty (who I remember as Lex Luthors partner in crime in the Christopher Reeve Superman films)) and Drew (Ronny Cox).The film actually starts pretty slow for the first twenty minutes or so and struggled to keep my attention. What follows is a shocking scene of the assault of Bobby by a couple of locals and the murder in self defence of the attackers by Lewis by arrow.What follows is an hour or so of Survival Of The Fittest scenes as the group contemplate their next moves in disposing of the body, covering their tracks and getting back down river to the 'safety' of their cars and home!
Of course it isn't as simple as that what with some questionnable locals who are set to lose their land and towns because of the dam project.The film features a musical score reminiscent of Ennio Morrocone's themes from the Dollars Trilogy, an unforgettable "feudin' banjos" scene as Drew duets with a local blind boy with a banjo.The sexual assault of Bobby is of course shocking but the resultant story is edge of your seat stuff."Squeal like a pig."

I remember reading the book years ago and finding it to be pretty thrilling. I can't say as I found the same in the movie.  There were some suspenseful moments but overall a great amount of tedium.  The characters were strongly lacking in anything of interest most especially that portrayed by Burt Reynolds.  The scenery on the other hand was fantastic.  Best I can say for this one is I managed to stay awake the entire time it was on.

reviews.review_title: An amazing film full of crockpot nonsense
reviews.content: Here's an example of a film that's greatness seems to transcend it's own bad ideas. Seen as a statement about the importance of survival and meeting challenges in being a man, it's really not very good, and doesn't really manage to deal with these ideas in the way that a film like "Straw Dogs" does. Reynolds's character is sort of the film's mouthpiece and he's frankly a bit of an idiot. But viewed as an action film, it's incredible ... one of the best ever made. It's a finely tuned machine with almost no spare parts and features some truly incredible cinematography from Vilmos Zsigmond and at least 5 incredible performances.

An excellent thriller about man's struggle to survive in the environment. Deliverance shows how men adapt to changing conditions in their surroundings. Will they have the inner strength to overcome the obstacles? Can they unleash their uncivilized self? These are the questions that James Dickey asks of his characters. This is an exciting journey of self exploration.

reviews.review_title: A masterful film that exposes a naked reality hiding behind male bravado.
reviews.content: "Deliverance" is a movie that demands that its characters put up or shut up. I am sure this film has meant many things to many different people, but to me, this is one of the strongest themes of the movie.  Four "city-slickers" go into the wild for a weekend canoe trip, acting like trail-blazing pioneers courageously exploring a vanishing frontier.  But early in the story, we see evidence that they are way out of their element.  They have entered a place that they can't easily understand or come to terms with, without ever even leaving their own state.  As they look for someone to drive them and their canoes upriver, we see in the background the harsh poverty and backwardness of the mountain folk.  It is as if the four men are in a completely different world where all things new have failed to penetrate and the rules are not the same as in the big city.  Yet, they seem oblivious to it all, and go about their male-bonding by recklessly canoeing down a wild and untame river and drinking large amounts of beer as if they are in some Old Milwaukee commercial.  They have come to conquer the wilderness, much like civilization is infringing upon this forgotten place by damming up the river and flooding the gorge.
