But as the trip suddenly goes horribly wrong, the men are forced to reveal what they are really all about inside.  Ned Beatty's frail character is stripped of all his dignity by a mountain man in a very disturbing yet powerful rape scene, and then has to rise off the ground and deal with his shame in it's aftermath.  Burt Reynold's character, a gungho survivalist freak is exposed as actually being weak when he is injured and has to rely on his friends to survive.  Ronny Cox seems doomed from the start as he fails to deal with the situation they all find themselves in.  And The character played by Jon Voight is faced with the morally trying task of killing a man to defend himself when earlier in the film he can't even bring himself to shoot a deer.  The film takes these four macho men and puts them to the test.  Just like in real life, some of the men pass the test, and some of them fail, but what they are really made of on the inside has by the end of the movie replaced what they have tried to say about themselves on the outside.  Machismo is humbled.  I particularly enjoy seeing this because in today's world, so many people, both men and women take unnecessary risks with their lives in order to achieve some ridiculously short-lived thrill.  Watching Voight's torturing ordeal to make it through this mess he has gotten himself into so he can get back alive to those he loves brings to light what is really important, and that there are plenty of thrills to be had making love to your wife and watching your children grow up and give you grandchildren.  One only needs to look at what happened to Kennedy Jr. to see where silly risk taking leads.

I remember the first time i saw this movie, and I can tell you that I didn`t understand it because I was only 10 years old.  But I remeber that we talked about it on the next day at school....( we were 10 years old and we discussed it... crazy..)Thats the effect Deliverance had on me at that time.. Now in the year 2002 I`ve seen it maybe 7-8 times because it touches something inside, maybe its fear of the "wilderness" or just what might happen to you on a river trip... But most of all I liked it because of the "real" stuff.... this aint Hollywood... How your life can be turned upside down in a couple of hours in these days of globalization...(1972-2002) Somebody outside the "system" takes control, NATURE!!!!and the people that lives there are the "Know-how" and we are just the players in a crude but beautiful nature...  Dont mess with nature, it bites back!! (ned beatty really plays a big a part in this movie.. EXCELLENT!) It`s the most unfucked, unpolluted, unspoild, untouched movie of the 20th centuryThe music is great...

This sumptuous looking film tells the story of four big city boys who go on a rafting adventure in the Deep South to find themselves but end up discovering things they rather wouldn't have. Echoing the great American novel Huck Finn they attempt to tame a treacherous stretch of the Mississippi before it is dammed by constructors and the naturalist theme of man not knowing or respecting his environment enough which rings through that book is seen here too, sometimes disturbingly. From the moment Burt Reynolds crashes a jeep recklessly through the woods trying to find the launch point "by instinct" having thrown away their map, one can tell that these men have no idea what awaits them. Reynolds is (for once) excellent as the archetypal alpha-male who leads his timid friends into the breach but is crippled by the river. Better still is Voight though, who finds it in himself to take another man's life; clearly the thinker amongst the group, his transition to cold blooded killer is utterly convincing to watch; the point, that we all still have our natural instincts within us but they are suppressed by our sanitized everyday lives, is well made. This transition is speeded by seeing his friend raped by bandits - again signifying how unnatural the whole episode is and how out of (their) place these boys from the city really are. The relief when they reach the end of their trip and return to civilization is palpable and heightened by how inevitably slow the descent into disaster has been. Indeed the whole film is wonderfully paced. Forget the much parodied banjo scene, this film is a disturbing and well written tale of civilized men going back to nature and discovering that they are neither ready nor willing for its trials.

From the onset Deliverance sets itself as different and special movie, distancing itself from the usual adventure canoe movies (such as Curtis Hanson's River Wild (1994)).  The much-heralded "Duel Banjo" scene is a spectacular and unnerving start to the film- Ronny Cox's character, whilst waiting in a desolate "gas" station strums up his guitar with a strange-looking inbred child playing on his banjo.  The scene that follows is as brilliant as it is disturbing and the music becomes a soundtrack for the rest of the film.The four canoeists (Reynolds, Voight, Beatty, Cox) trip down the River (soon to be flooded by a huge lake- a very neat twist from writer Dickey) doesn't become a trip to survive nature as one assumes it will be, but a fight for survival from fellow men. And what men!!! The nemesis of  the canoists turns out to be a duo of inbred hillbillies (rotting teeth et al). Making the hillbillies the villans is a terrifying touch-  their faces contorted in ugliness, with seemingly no sense of morals and humanity.   The most uncomfortable scene of the film is the male-rape scene ("Squeel like a piggy!")- but don't let it put you off seeing the movie.It's not flawless, however.  The film makes very uncomfortable viewing (and essentially unsatisfying) and you never feel a real attachment with the protaganists but if you like your movies with a bit of originality and horror this is the one for you...Reynolds puts in one of his better perfomances and Jon Voight (father of Angelina Jolie) acts in what probably is his best performance to date.  Boormans direction is sound, and this is undoubtably one of his best movies.The film turns into an apocalyptic struggle for the canoeists, and Boorman creates a nightmarish hell that will play upon your mind for days to come- and put you off canoeing for life...
8/10

Casting Director Lynn Stalmaster certainly did a superlative job in selecting her four leading actors for this harrowing project.
Messrs. Voight, Reynolds, Beatty and Cox were all young, strong, talented and totally committed to both their craft in general and roles in particular.  It's one thing to perform dangerous stunts for the camera with insurance--extremely risky business without, as in this case.  Of course, no reputable company would risk financing a cast and crew in paddleboats braving the treacherous rapids of South Carolina's lake jocassee and Georgia's Chattooga River.  Especially commendable was Mr. Voight's volunteering to do his own stuntwork, in one scene scaling a 95 degree mountainside--with Vilmos Zsigmond's camera teetering close at hand.  Yet it is these potentially perilous scenes which give this drama its special edge.Fortunately for all concerned, no serious physical mishaps occurred, and the production wrapped intact.  There's no doubt that all involved realized they were working on a very high quality project, and elected to give it their all.  Mr. Reynolds in particular may chalk this one up as his finest career achievement. Whatever concerns may have occurred between Director Boorman and Writer Dickey, along with other productional challenges, is now moot, as appreciative audiences continue to be thrilled by this solid enactment of Dickey's novel-based screenplay.

reviews.review_title: Uh, did I miss something here??
reviews.content: I could not believe that Deliverance was in the top 250 movies of IMDb...this is ridiculous...Many people told me there was a lot of suspense in this film, but one friend of mine told me the opposite...and he was right...I didn't like the characters and I didn't care if they were going to die or not. And the rape scene was disgusting, but the victim didn't seem to care after the aggression. The story is about four guys who want to have fun by travelling on a river. But there are two bad guys who rape one of them, and one of them tries to kill the others after they killed the rapist. As you can see, the story is pathetic. The acting of Jon Voight was good, but Burt Reynolds was stupid as the fearless leader of the gang. The scenario was very simple and there were some of the lines that were soooooo bad! One other thing, the tagline tells the final situation of the film...and the ending was boring too....I just can't understand why this film is SO overrated?!! A very ordinary movie, doesn't bring anything special...I didn't like it very much...I give it 61%.

My mother tells me that, when she and Dad saw this flick in the theaters, people LAUGHED at Ned Beatty getting buggered. I never knew about the rape until I saw the uncut version. This is a story of man against nature and, as always, losing. Beatty's character, being the most out of place in nature, bore the brunt. Nature rose up against an outsider and, quite literally, raped him. Why did people laugh? I have read the novel, after seeing the flick, as most people, I'm sure. It is my understanding that Dickey wrote the book to explain a vision or dream he kept having about a man standing atop a rocky gorge over a rapid river. Brilliant. The thing the movie leaves out, that the book makes SO important, is the thinking of Voight's character as he climbs the wall. You get in his mind in the book. The movie leaves it to the cinema, which is outstanding nonetheless. It wasn't funny then, and it isn't funny now.It was real, it was a wonderful work...of art.

I saw this shortly after it came out, and thought it was quite gruesome then. It still is, but as for film-making,
it's just OK.Here's my breakdown:STORY:
"When white-water rafting goes bad ..." and in this case, really bad.I thought the writers tried / attempted to spawn sub-plots that would hold together, and sometimes they did,
sort of. But more often, this was a painfully long string of cliches, and never resolved any meaningful sub or main plot.This seemed a very poor attempt at a central theme of cultural and environmental change. It ends up largely as a
platform giving Reynolds his alpha-male role. And as I've said before, stories that pivot around a "prima donna" always
end up anorexic from expending its energy on one person, and the whole is sorely compromised.ACTING:
The acting here is OK, but barely. The acting and script were so predictable and rife with cliche ... it becomes very tiresome.Reynolds, like so many other actors, get put on a pedestal and then we make film that pivots around them. (I could make a long list.)
This is so bad in that vein that you could call this the "Burt Reynolds Show."ENTERTAINMENT:
Moderate value for most, I suspectTEMPO:
Very slow mostly, which is sometimes an asset, but more often it just weighs down the flowCINEMATOGRAPHY:
Beautiful for the most part, and is sadly, the best part of the filmMUSIC / SOUND:
OKDIRECTING / WRITING:
Director: Boorman directed and co-wrote this, which as you may know, is a very bad call 99% of the time IMO.This, along with his TV pedigree, made for what I thought was a mediocre story and a poor script.Writers: This was Dickey's first (of 2) screenplay. It shows.Is it a good film? Yes, and no.Should you watch this once? Yes. Maybe.Rating: 7.0.

Deliverance is just as powerful a movie as it was in 1972. I still believe it is Burt Reynolds best movie, (except maybe Boogie Nights.) and Jon Voight put in a very strong performance.It was different in the way movies are made today. It actually showed you how the characters felt after the major events took place. Where now days the movie just ends sending the message that explosions and gun play are all that matters.

I am writing this 'review' to address most of the negative comments aimed at this movie in the majority of the negative reviews that I have read here at IMDb.  Spoilers may be revealed."the story/plot wasn't good" - Though I disagree, this movie isn't really about the plot.  Sure, there are specific events that had to happen within a certain sequence to form a backdrop, but that is NOT what this movie is about.  The movie is about the characters' journey, their reaction to the circumstances they encounter.  I found myself thinking "what would I do?" many times while watching this movie.  That is a sure sign of a character film.  The plot is not detailed because it doesn't have to be.
"There were only like 10 lines of dialogue" - umm, were we watching the same movie?  Not only is there a decent amount of dialogue but it all sounds like REAL people talking.  For example - after the guy who rapes Bobby is killed, none of the typical Hollywood "yeah die you sick fuck!" type dialogue exists.  Instead you hear the thoughts of four normal men pour out about the realization that they have just taken the life of another human being. I'll take this dialogue over Elisabeth Shue yelling "I'll show you hell!" in 'Hollow Man' any day."the acting was bad" - Could you do it?  Have you ever been in a situation like that the characters in this movie faced?  Unlikely, and I doubt that Voight, Beatty, Cox or Reynolds have either.  Given that circumstance ALONE, I believe the performances in the film to be outstanding.
There are other things I could address, but if you don't agree with me up to this point then I won't even bother.  Just go rent 'Scary Movie' again and I'm sure you'll be happy.

reviews.review_title: One of those Iconic Films Never to be Forgotten
reviews.content: How can you not watch a movie that is brought up in pop culture as often as Deliverance? I mean it is one of Sterling Archer's favourites, so that should be enough said.In all seriousness though, Deliverance has a few of those scenes that will never be forgotten such as the banjo duelling, and the infamous 'squealing' scene. With that disturbing scene, you could say it was way ahead of its time, as I don't think many people who watched it when it first came out would have expected that; talk about shock value. Props have to be given to Ned Beatty's character considering what happened to him, he handled it like a champ the remainder of the story. Burt Reynolds screams manliness in the first half, while Jon Voight picks up the slack in the second.Really an amazing achievement getting all those shots and stunts while on the river. Definitely a wild ride. Bet they wish they just went golfing in the end.

reviews.review_title: What Lies Buried Beneath the Lake?
reviews.content: "It's all up to you, Ed?" "Now you get to play the game." The day my father left my mother, he took me to see this film with his new girlfriend, on opening day at the Cinerama Dome in Hollywood. I was but fourteen years old. I wasn't even entirely sure what I was seeing, but I will never forgot it, especially the scene with Ned Beatty.Watching it today, thirty-six years later, it still gives me quivers.My father was a huge Burt Reynolds fan, hence the reason for standing in line for almost an hour in to watch what was supposed to be an 'action movie.' I had seen two films at the Dome prior to this: "Grand Prix" and "The Song of Norway." Well this wasn't exactly Mario Andretti or The Brady Bunch. After leaving the theater, I was shell-shocked.But even at that tender age, I appreciated the artistry...and after seeing again today, am I surprised I was still standing after witnessing this highly disturbing, yet extremely well-crafted film.Suffice it to say it was a traumatic experience for a fourteen year-old that had yet to kiss his first girlfriend. I don't blame my father for taking me, but it was a bit much for a child to witness.As an adult, I still find it quite disturbing, yet I am still very impressed with the quality of the film-making.Burt Reynolds as an absolute wonder, as are all the principles...from Billy Redden as the inbred guitar wonder, to Ronny Cox as the terrified insurance salesman...everyone does an admirable job. The sound quality is second to none, from the chirping birds to the ticking clocks. The photography, cinematography...all the technical aspects of this remarkable film are first rate.The moral questions raised, from murdering the sexual assaulters to the aftermath of dealing with killing a human being, remain as profound today as they did when this groundbreaking film was released. And the classic sequences of attempting to survive in the wilderness after dealing with such unforeseen brutality are life-altering. These four men, city men, suddenly confronted with a situation with never imagined, raise the bar from action to horror.It's a classic to be sure. And the phrase "you have a pretty mouth" has been quoted endlessly, from Saturday Night Live to off-the-cuff comments around water-cooler at work, this movie is without a doubt a huge part of our societal pop culture...as much as "Make my day" or "I'll be back" ever were.So what would YOU do if you found your friends being sexually assaulted at gunpoint by mountain men far away from your life in the city, cozy bed, wife and kids? And if you took the measures Burt Reynolds did (and I would have done the same) would you bury the body beneath the soon-to-be-lake, or stand trial and take your chances? The bottom line is: Deliverance delivers. You can take that to the bank. If this movie doesn't get under your skin, then you are not human.Even if you have seen this before, rent it again and ask yourself the above question.My favorite part of the film remains the same: Ed failing to kill the deer...then changing. Life and it's unpredictable circumstance can change a man. And I suppose that's what this film is all about Jon Voight, in particular, as Ed, gives the best performance here. And he remains one of the more gifted actors in Hollywood history, from Midnight Cowboy to his highly underrated performance as Franklin D. Roosevelt in Pearl Harbor, his acting lifts the movie to another level. Climbing the rocks at dusk, terrified and determined to make it right It needs to be seen to be believed. I guarantee your heart rate will elevated to a new level.Briskly paced, tense, taut and tightly drawn as a as a banjo string, this is a morality play that asks questions that remain today. Times have changes, but our choices as human beings have not.Ten out of ten stars.

reviews.review_title: Better think twice about that family canoeing trip.
reviews.content: I like Deliverance. It's a great movie about revenge and male-bonding. It also has one of the most frightening, twisted, memorable scenes in all of motion picture history. In every man's worst nightmare Ned Beatty and the words "Squeal like a pig, boy!" dominate the pit of all our fears. It is a truly horrific scene. The movie is well acted by Mr. Beatty, Burt Renyolds, Jon Voight, and Ronny Cox. And the outdoor cinematography is breathtaking. But there's two things that stand out in this movie that make me love it. One is dueling banjos. The scene between the kid and the guy playing is one of the coolest songs ever. It rocks. I love when the kid breaks into warp-speed ho-down mode. The second thing I love is Ed O'Niell's first ever screen appearance. Being a huge Married With Children fan I have come to regard anything with Ed O'Niell as worth watching. And this being his first time in front of a camera is well.......Awesome. Deliverance starts with dueling banjos and ends with Ed O'Niell, in between is one of the greatest movies ever.

reviews.review_title: Back in the day Guys were FREAKED OUT by this movie! :O
reviews.content:
This classic nightmare of a story is well written, well acted and back in the day was SHOCKING!! Most guy's were terrified by that one INFAMOUS scene. Now it seems even straight guys all wanna be NED Beatty's character. LOL. :o
This movie still holds up in 2021 and definitely worth a watch. The Dueling Banjo's is still Awesome! ;D.

reviews.review_title: The best film of John Boorman, and a testament of Burt Reynolds talent as an actor.
reviews.content: Extremely brutal film, it is arguably the best performance in the career of Burt Reynolds, and may be John Boorman,'s finest. I always thought that Mr. Boorman was among the best filmmakers ever - him, David Cronenberg and John Frankenheimer. Sadly, none of these three ever won an Academy Award. I read the novel by James Dickey, which I think is a more suitable vehicle for such a powerful story of man versus nature, in a sense that the author uses the advantage of not being limited to budget or time constriction. In paper, Deliverance is even more gripping than the movie, and you get to know what happens for the surviving members of the adventure once they come back to civilization. I remember Dickey's prose, describing the Jon Voight character in the novel, coming back to civilization after the ordeal, the buildings gradually appearing, the mountains behind, but the river, although far, perennial and now a part of himself. Some of the best poetic things about the novel couldn't be translated to the film, but this 1972 movie stood the test of time. It builds atmosphere, and it is a testament for the quality of the writing and the direction, that even with not much happening, the film is breathtaking and tense, and when tragedy strikes, it's a roller-coaster. I recommend this one.

Four friends from Atlanta take two canoes down a river that is soon to disappear due to the building of a dam. On their way, they get into serious trouble with some local rednecks - an experience that forces them to question their moral values and cultural norms. 'Deliverance' is an excellently acted film that is beautifully photographed and perfectly directed by John Boorman - in fact, it is by a good margin the best of Boorman's films I have watched so far. I was particularly impressed by Burt Reynolds as the tough-playing big city boy who leads his friends into trouble and by Ned Beatty as his rather timid companion who seems to find some inner strength. Typically for 1970s films, there is no hero (though there are some obvious villains) and it is being left open whether in the end goodness has prevailed. Moral ambiguity is the hallmark of 'Deliverance'. Excellent film, highly recommended.

John Boorman's powerfully gripping classic thriller which is based on the best selling novel by James Dickey, who also wrote the captivating and richly-layered screenplay. It concerns four businessmen who set out on a whitewater rafting trip down the wild Cuhulawassee river in Georgia, but their adventure soon becomes a nightmare of survival when they encounter two demented mountain men, chillingly played by the Bill McKinney and Herbert Coward. Their innocent nature trip turns into a life and death struggle lace with murder. Fascinating and highly suspenseful throughout with beautiful cinematography by Vilmos Zsigmond. Magnificently acted by the entire cast particularly Burt Reynolds in the finest dynamic performance of his iconic career, as Lewis the strong-willed natural leader of the men, Jon Voight delivers a marvelous turn as Ed, the sensitive man who finds he wants to release his primitive instincts when his life is at sake. Ned Beatty makes his impressive big screen debut as Bobby the city slicker member of the group who is brutally raped by Bill McKinney's sadistic mountain man; this was the first cinematic on screen depiction of male rape, and Ronny Cox delivers a fine performance as Drew the quiet family man who is completely overwhelmed by the grueling events. Boorman's brilliant Oscar nominated direction triumphantly turned Dickey's acclaimed novel into a thrilling and inspired cinematic masterpiece. A landmark American film that was nominated for 3 Academy Awards including Best Picture.NOTE: "Deliverance" has been selected by the Library of Congress to the National Film Registry to be preserved for being a culturally and historically significant motion picture.

I ordered this movie a few days ago after reading a lot of reviews of Deliverance. It's been told so much good things about this movie so I wanted to check it out. I saw it and after seeing it I didn't know I liked it or not. I still don't know. I can't just decide it. It was good but it was just not how I expected it to be. It was a little disappointment. I thought there would be more violence and a bit of suspense but it wasn't. The acting was great but there was something missing in the story. I just don't know what. I loved the kid with the banjo. Hewas cool. Oh well...I just don't know what more to say about the movie.I'm speechless.

I saw this movie because everyone who saw it told me its disturbing features will make you think twice about going down south...i have to say that this movie was pretty cool...though i found nothing disturbing about the film i did see some things i didnt care for...the movie did indeed make an impact...i dont believe that this is a spoiler but the the kid at the beginning of the movie is by far the creepiest looking kid i have ever seen in my life...the scary possum kid is what i call him...above all the weird stuff this movie gives us a better understanding of how these certain people live...and let me tell you this, i am never going down south...i will admit that towards the end its a bit lengthy but above hat i would actually buy this movie and i will because some of the strange images have not left my head....you go figure...go out and rent it if you could find it!!!!

A bleak story about the superficiality of civilisation, turned into an accomplished, atmospheric, beautifully photographed, strangely disturbing movie, which thankfully wasn't made by Sam Peckinpah but came instead into the more compassionate orbit of John Boorman, who elicits a quartet of four superb performances from Voight, Reynolds, Beatty and Cox. Voight deserves special commendation: from the moment the story takes its extremely violent turn, his eyes express everything you could ever want to know.There's a sense in which we've been here before: the imagery of the river journey into human degradation is reminiscent of Conrad's HEART OF DARKNESS. The extra stuff we get here - scaling the rockface, the imminent inundation of the land - makes for good pictures but I'm not sure it adds much else. The thing about this sort of fiction is it doesn't go beyond the statement of what I regard as a fact: we're all a step away from savagery. Compare and contrast that real masterpiece, Croenenberg's A HISTORY OF VIOLENCE, for a more profound examination of the human condition.

This movie is one of the darkest experiences I've ever had in my life in front of a TV. I remember being very young and this movie left me traumatized for months. I even had nightmares. It scared me so much that I only watched it again years later and only once. It's not an easy movie. However, it is a masterpiece of psychological thriller, with performances that could easily deliver Golden Globes and Oscars to multiple actors.

reviews.review_title: Repulsive, Sickening, Horrifying, Disturbing, Gross->Just Plain Awful!
reviews.content: If you have ever seen a movie where it disturbs you beyond belief, then you have seen Deliverance. Deliverance is one of those movies that seems like it would have lots of action but in fact it has one very repulsive scene with male rape and torture. There is also an impalement part in that scene that is good but at the same time horrifying. All in all, I hate this movie with a passion!My Take: 3/10 My MPAA Rating: R for strong disturbing violent content including a perverse rape scene, and for language.

A lot has happened and movies have changed much in the 28 years since Deliverance hit the big screen. Perhaps the simplicity of this movie does not appeal so much to those raised on the fantastic mega-buck blockbusters from Hollywood...but to me it  still seems fresh and probably deserves the "classic" label so often tagged on to it.  Deliverance stays in your mind long after you first see it - and I find that it is eminently suitable for repeated viewings.  The simplicity of this movie is part of its charm. The DVD release of Deliverance also demonstrates the beautiful photographic images which match anything filmed today - it is hard to believe this movie is almost 30 years old!  What a pity they don't make 'em like this anymore!

I recall seeing this film on TV some years ago and not paying full attention, maybe even missing the first half, so I came to the conclusion that it was dull and over rated. I decided to revisit it last night to see if I had missed anything the first time. I certainly did. This is one of the most disturbing and amazing films of all time and it has clearly had much influence on films today and probably will forever. I can't believe I thought this film was boring! A young Jon Voight and Burt Reynolds give the performances of their careers and are supported by Ned Beatty and Ronny Cox. This story will leave you with a sense of disgust and dread long after you watch it, it is truly horrifying. Oh, and did I mention that the theme song is great, as well? Well it is, and this movie should be seen by movie fans everywhere.Everyone should see this movie for the experience. Just don't expect a picnic.

reviews.review_title: Decent film, but what was the point?
reviews.content: Ultimately this one was highly controversial for its time, back in 1972, but after it's all over you are left wondering what the principle was. If indeed there was one. A group of 4 friends go on a canoo trip to the outer reaches of the USA, in Hillbilly country. After encountering some strange individuals they embark on rapids, then setup camp. Then things start to go wrong, and the whole trek becomes a question of survival.Back in the 70's this was powerful stuff, but these days it's fairly timid.The story is well told, but several moments are utterly unbelievable, and hard to let pass, though due to the good acting we can.The ending is a little blase, really, almost contrived, but ultimately it's a half decent yarn and worth watching.Especially for Duelling Banjoes.

reviews.review_title: The best thing I can say about this movie film is thank God it wasnt filmed in my home state!
reviews.content: Some movies just dont hold up over time and this is a good example. I remember this flick had much more impact on it's release, it was different and I guess it appealed to all us closet banjo pickers that fantasized about marrying our aunts, cousins, sisters, mothers, etc. And if you've ever been whitewater rafting there's not much about the Cuhulawasassawasee that will intimidate you. And as far as that whole "pig" thing goes, I always felt Ned Beatty was the wrong guy for that scene...my choice would have been Ronny Cox onacounta the fact that any Y chromosome deficient that brings a guitar along on a camping trip with his buddies is just asking for it. Hey, come to think of it, maybe thats why him a Burt were late showing up for the rescue? Boooooring! 5/10

I watched this film again the other night after not seeing it since 1973. I've also read many of the comments on this site. Most of the comments are good and valid...the struggle of man against nature... the macho vs the reflective... but I didn't see one comment on what I think to be the most compelling aspect of this wonderful movie. That is, I think it is one of the best "who done-it" plots of all time. The fact that we never really know whether or not the four city slickers were being pursued from the start or whether or not Voight shot the wrong guy or not... But there are clues. Like the shot of three guys in the woods when the trip set out up river, when there were only two guys that followed them in the truck. At first we think it is the same guys that agreed to drive the cars. But where did the third come from? Were they even the same guys or some others? And why did the sheriff ask Voight if the two guys who agreed to drive the cars had a third with them? Did he suspect something about three crazed buggers haunting those parts? Or did he suspect that the missing brother-in-law may have been with them? And other minor clues... The guy that Voight shot on the top of the gorge had a wedding ring that the directors were key to focus on. Brother-in-law of the guy in Aintry as he suggested? Also, there aren't many bridges in that neck of the woods. The rape scene was on the right bank. Voight shot the second victim on the left bank. Careless or meaningless direction? I don't think so. Not from Boorman. But do I know what it all means? Hell no, but it is worth buying the DVD and doing a closer study. I think there is an answer in there somewhere. But if anyone else has it figured out, please let me know. Fascinating.

"Deliverance" is one of the best exploitation films to come out of that wonderful 1970's decade from whence so many other exploitation films came.A group of friends sets out on a canoe trip down a river in the south and they become victimized by a bunch of toothless hillbillies who pretty much try to ruin their lives. It's awesome.We are treated to anal rape, vicious beatings, bow and arrow killings, shootings, broken bones, etc... A lot like 1974's "Texas Chainsaw Massacre," to say that "Deliverance" is believable would be immature. This would never and could never happen, even in the dark ages of 1972."Deliverance" is a very entertaining ride and packed full of action. It is one in a huge pile of exploitation films to come from the early 70's and it (arguably) sits on top of that pile with it's great acting, superb cinematography and excellent writing.8 out of 10, kids.

So one of the keywords for this title is "inbreeding." Huh. I don't know nothing' about no "inbreedin" but I sho nuff have a suspicion that it don't involve having sex with no men. Neither.James Dickey had a very odd sense of humor. This movie manages to capture a part of his essential "smart-aleckiness" and provides fuel for a million hours of hysterical reading--if you are inclined to read the various reviews written by city-slickers who really, really want to find something out in the woods.Or lose something.The genius of this film, which may hold the record for the most "hands on" involvement by the author, is that it portrays the surreal adventure of the murderous dudes without a single giggle to betray the joke. The joke's on you, America. Get those hillbillies! Get 'em now! Oh the horror! Ned Beatty! Burt Reynolds! And that dead guy! It's all par for the course in the great American "I'm not like those fools" parlor game of American boys and men everywhere. Listen as they critique the peculiarities of Dickey's weird universe of banjo pickin' feebs and arrow shootin' dweebs. Listen, boy. Jes lizzen.Damn fine movie. Taken seriously by all real manly men everywhere.

reviews.review_title: Shattered my expectations, but Reynolds is brilliant
reviews.content: "Deliverance" is a 1972 adventure thriller directed by John Boorman starring Jon Voight and Burt Reynolds. Upon the passing of the legend that Burt Reynolds is, I became aware of the existence of this film, as it is not only cited as his breakthrough role, but also as one of the best films he has ever starred in. For a long time that film faded from the spotlight and I wasn't able to get hold of a copy of this film and never thought I would be ever getting it, but then, earlier this year, it was all suddenly recommended to me and since it was on sale, I purchased it. I was extremely stoked to finally see what everyone was talking about and to see if the high ratings on several platform actually hold up to the quality of the film. In my case, I was severely disappointed by the final outcome. Do you know this situation when you come along a movie that is completely different to what is said about it in advertisements and other forms of summaries? It is not quite different with this one. For example, I previously read about it and found out that this classic is one of the biggest influences for the British horror gem "The Descent" and even though I of course didn't expect to witness the same kind of gore fest that this film is, I hoped to at least see the "realistic horror" this classic film is praised for and that it would at least shock me in this context. Sadly, it didn't and that isn't the only thing that didn't resonate with me. First of all, it was almost impossible for me to find some sort of connection to any of the characters at all, as most of the shots in the beginning, the most ideal moment to introduce your characters to the audience, mainly consisted of wide shots that literally made it hard for me to get close to them. It is such a pity, as I like "Midnight Cowboy" Jon Voight as an actor, but I simply could not find sympathy to them at all. The only one that genuinely had me curious was Reynolds's Lewis. Not only was he in an extraordinarily good shape, with the vest and the bow he also was an extremely charismatic and iconic character that I immediately began to like. Furthermore, I felt how a conflict-laden interdependence between him and Ed began to develop and that this film would put their weird friendship on a test quite frequently, I mean, one is a city person to the core and the other is an outdoor fanatic and a nature boy who loves the extreme. There could have been a lot of conflict potential in the air and this could have been one of the biggest strengths of this flick, but as you can guess from how I phrase this sentence, this really didn't happen. After playing a more or less significant role in an early scene he then is incapacitated and thus degraded to a useless side character who doesn't add anything to the plot anymore. This wasn't only heavily disappointing to see in general, it simultaneously shattered my expectations to see some tension between the two. Instead, the focus lies on Ed from there on and how he puts on a one man show, but this doesn't change the fact that as a character, he still is underdeveloped and uninteresting. The only thing that gave him some personality was being the total opposite of Lewis, but since this bond is broken like a bone quite quickly, there is nothing left that made him interesting to follow in any way. Another thing that heavily displeased me was the experimental score. Except for some banjo tones and the famous duel in the beginning, the film refrains from using any from of sound score. While I do understand that this was a stylistic device to underline the roughness and tantalizing mercilessness of nature, it was extremely irritating to me personally. Sounds and any form of background music are there to create atmosphere in a film and support the tension. It is a common fact and there are only a few exceptions were the procedure of omitting it works out, but in those cases, it is only for a few sequences, not the other way around. So, who the hell thought it was a great idea to follow this strategy for a whole feature film? Not only was it almost impossible for me to perceive any form of atmosphere, it on top of that appeared uncomfortably soporific to me. In case of a film that promised to depict an adrenaline-fuelled white-water rafting per excellence, this is nothing but a shame. The plot of the film doesn't make it any better. What is said about this film on the summary on the back of the physical copy makes me assume that I would witness a cruel fight for survival, the ultimate battle of man versus nature. Well, aside from some minor obstacles and an altercation with some backwoodsmen there wasn't something I would consider to be an immense and life-threatening danger. To be honest, they all got out of the situation surprisingly easily and almost unharmed. Of course one of their friends was killed (although it obviously looked like suicide to me), one was raped by a hillbilly and another broke his upper leg along the way, but aside from that they are neither lost nor did it in any way seem that they wouldn't make it out alive. I was sure from quite early in the film that they would all get out of there and that predictability made it boring rather than packing. Also, after some time, it was just annoying to follow the remaining guys, as the scenes only contained of them shouting each other's names continuously. In the end, I knew their names, but still that wasn't enough for me to like them, nor was it enough for them to have a personality. Even when the film tried to focus more on the moral dilemma after they killed two men and on how they cope with this delicate topic, this actually interesting aspect wasn't elaborated well enough either. Oh, let's also not forget about the intended social criticism on how humankind destroys nature that was implied right in the beginning. The biggest problem of the film is how it wants to include all of those said aspects but doesn't manage to find a main focus. Instead, all of them are lighted only half heartedly and get lost along the way. Also, the final twenty minutes in which they try to cover up their crimes and try to deal with their guilty conscience just lacks the intensity that is required in an extremely emotional sequence like that. All in all, this film heavily disappointed me and my high expectations, as it wasn't either packing nor in any way threatening to me. Too many things just didn't resonate with me and too many decisions were questionable in my opinion and in the end, I was mainly bored than actually excited. The characters had no personality and the story was way too tame to be called a wild ride. It didn't impact me in the slightest and in the end, was forgettable rather than a cinematic masterpiece as apparently everyone makes it out to be. When I watch a film that is supposedly bad and I end up disliking it, it of course is still a bad film, but not surprise at all. On the other hand, when I hope to see brilliance and prepared myself accordingly and the film ends up being bad, it is a different and more shattering kind of disappointment. The only thing I praise in this film is Burt Reynolds's great but way too short performance, but that's already all. In the end, this film is the cinematic equivalent of a tranquil creek, rather than rapid stream as it is said to be. Shattered my expectations like a canoe on a rock.

reviews.review_title: One of the greatest movies ever made
reviews.content: But so distressing I have never been able to watch it again. It is so realistic and the acting so true....the whole story reaks of realness....I just haven't been able to watch it again.

reviews.review_title: Where do you find your manhood?
reviews.content: This has always been a favorite of mine, full of suspense and drama. and it positively drips with symbolism. Everything means something. And theres alot more to it than male rape, although that's the most memorable scene {probably in history}. There isn't a man who's seen this film who didn't fantasize about "boy, if that were me in the woods..."   A  Two final thoughts about Deliverance: It shows Burt Renyolds can ACT. And the primal fear movie is the best.

'Deliverance' is scary because it's rooted in reality. You KNOW something like it has happened somewhere. Bestial, inbred hillbillies are a lot more frightening than clowns with chainsaws.The acting is great, even on Burt Reynolds' part. And since Brando refused his lead actor Oscar that year, it should have gone to Jon Voight. Ned Beatty is great, too.

I just saw this movie and i must say it really wasn't that good at all. How some people can say this movie is one the best movies of time is way beyond me. To be blunt about it, it was very boring. I kept waiting for "something" to happen but nothing really ever does. That movie should have been made in about 30 min. The film kept showing them rafting over and over again. VERY VERY REPETITIVE. Thought this movie must have cool ending because of all the hype, but it was a huge letdown. This is one of the most overrated films i have ever seen. The only neat thing about is the atmosphere, and the realism to the film. Other than that it is very subpar. 4/10

Four urban men think it would be cool to be at one with nature for a weekend. Trespassing into another universe...three of them are vomited out with visible scars and invisible horrors--the other is dead. When the rules change--its not checkers anymore --nor is it chess. Quickly, in the twinkling of an eye, its survival. This movie takes no prisoners--what you see is what you maybe don't want to see. How you feel is maybe how you don't want to feel. Was it their condescending behavior in the presence of the simple mountain folks that came back to bite them? Perhaps. The adventure the four men were seeking--became a life or death struggle with nature...and another way of life.Perhaps they could have handled nature----but they could not handle those living "another way". Were the final decisions they made ..the right decisions? The only one who felt uneasy about their biggest decision died. This excellent movie challenges us --with a lot of questions. And demands our undivided attention.

I liked Deliverance mainly because the idea of this being a film shown widely in theaters was *awesome*. I wish I could have been there to see the audience's reaction. I didn't find it that disturbing myself, but I can see it having had a big impact. I loved the karmic theme of nature and her vengeance.. and how the urban people (environmental rapists) got raped themselves. The acting wasn't astounding and there were aspects of the script that needed work.. however, the concepts were good enough to make this worth watching once.

I had heard so many positive things about this movie... and I got so little. It is NOT the movie I expected. It's just an okay movie, with an okay story, and okay actors. It's watchable, but it's certainly not incredible, and yet it stood the test of time. How? I really don't know... Its just an okay movie about a bunch of city men going on a canoe trip, who get attacked by some crazy local folks. Pretty bad if you ask me. It did not have the psychological terror I had heard about. I had heard things like: "The way everything happens is so realistic..." and "It's great on many levels...". I don't know about you, but I sure didn't feel that way. I even think it was not convincing. Come on, if something like THIS can become a classic, almost anything can become one... If you want to see a great movie by John Boorman, watch Excalibur.6 out of 10(it's really generous if you ask me).

DELIVERANCE is a sprawling masterpiece.  The story is great, the characters rock, and the action never ceases to amaze.  Kudos to John Boorman and his cast for making a classic.  I would put this on my Top 10 of all time.   Ted's Grade: A

I've wanted to see this movie for years, but never had the chance. I finally saw it on TV last year and enjoyed it thoroughly. I think what I saw was edited a lot (TBS). Normally I'd be upset about the editing, but I only had to see Ned Beatty briefly in his underwear...so I guess I win on that one. Amazing acting, the banjo kid and that village were weird and scary in the worst way. This movie was a 9/10...and remember next time you go on a canoe trip, make sure there is a huge padlock on your titanium underwear.

The best reason to watch Deliverance is for the dueling banjos scene. Its all downhill from there. The plot is too long and drawn out with too many speechless and actionless "thinking" moments. Burt Reynolds, Jon Voight and Ned Beatty play their roles very well but this movie would have been much better if 30 to 45 minutes were cut out. All in all, the scenery is wonderful, the plot is intriguing but the execution is not there.My rating : @@ (out of five)

reviews.review_title: Dickey wrote a great screenplay and book.
reviews.content: It is a shame that James Dickey didn't write more movie scripts. This was a great book and movie.  His description of the "rock climbing" scene was superb.  His characterizations and the acting were stunning.

What is the underlying theme of this film? I think it is all about "crimes against nature," as well as a "think-piece" concerning the dichotomy of man's uneasy coexistence with nature. Destroying a picturesque river setting by flooding it to create a man-made dam; spearing fish with a modified high-power bow/arrow; using the river's naturally-formed rapids for a week-end adventure with little appreciation for the natural surroundings or the people who live there, etc. Let us not fail to add forced homosexual rape by sodomy; killing others with impunity; man's attempted ability to manipulate reality by telling mutually-agreed false stories - vs- nature's ability to reveal only facts. There are so many more such references that can be similarly drawn. I think that is the theme James Dickey was working with. Combine the effective picturesque prose of Dickey's novel with Boorman's vividly beautiful filming of the story and the result is a memorable film; probably more appreciated by history than it was when the film was initially released. I would agree the acting is fine, yet may be the weakest part of the final product. Nonetheless, this is a fine film - one of my favorites.

"Deliverance" is a dead-on example of what wonderful movies came out of the '70s. While your jaw is dropped during a "Terminator" movie, are you really sacred? I don't think so, because you are there to see what new CGIs have been strung together - plot matters not.So many daily situations can become terrifying for no reason at all, because there are so many people involved in daily living - like a trip to the market.....or a walk down a dimly-lighted street. "Deliverance" is SO frightening, because those innocent actions can turn deadly in a heart-beat. Venturing into the backwoods is a frolic in fun? Anyone who has that notion does not read the papers, watch the daily news, nor has not seen some of the other movies that depict the seriousness of "trespassing" into territories where outsiders are not welcome. It is almost unbelievable that the advance dish on "Deliverance" didn't inform almost everyone going to view it this was no picnic, and "squeal like a pig" wasn't a part of "Deulling Banjos".I hate the term "hillbillies", because - as some "users" wrote - that demeans entire regions of people who are very content to live as they know how - without the interference of modern life. Much is made of "inbred" - that is not sexuality peculiar to the backwoods. "Chinatown" should teach us that lesson. However, city-slickers are extremely dumb to enter a closed society and give them attitude. I know lots of "hillbillies" - they are moral people, when left to themselves. Their "justice" can be brutal when they feel threatened or humiliated, just like the "justice" in city streets. They don't need any part of the city - the city should take its canoe-ing and camping to legal sites."Deliverance" was the last film I found Jon Voight to do any real acting - I hope I'm wrong. He was extremely underpaid for "Midnight Cowboy", because he was unknown, but demonstrated that he could do that role at the drop of a hat. His acting in "Deliverance" was superb. It gave us a clear demonstration ordinary people can move mountains, if it's necessary - but who wants to be thought-of as "ordinary" today? His stifled sob at the dinner was brilliant. Wow! for Burt Reynolds !!! One must ask what led him into those other tacky films? His manliness, although misguided, in this film set the pace for the endurance necessary to make it out of the wilderness - not only in the backwoods, but the wilderness of everyday-life. Ned Beatty was stellar - his underwear may not have had "Versace" stitched on it, but his shell-shocked performance was perfect. As noted, he became stronger than any of the group by the end of the movie. Ronny Cox played the moral guy to the hilt - every man should have his determination to do what is right. Several "users" have theorized he was shot, or lost his balance when he pitched-into the river - my theory is that he was so disgusted with the whole journey, he committed suicide. No gunshot was heard during the scene and Voight and Beatty did not find a wound.James Dicey certainly knows how to weave a suspenseful tale, and was great as the sheriff - it is said he was so terrified of acting he came to the set drunk every day. His character could see the three canoe-rs were guilty of surviving, but also knew they didn't stand a chance against a jury of the local people, no matter how kindly they were treated in "Aintry". He was also aware that the meaner of the locals could be cruel. Justice ? - "don't come back up here again". Not many "users" knew "hillbillies" were used in the film where ever it was possible - what actors could portray them better? The "mountain-men" WERE actually mountain-men.......Every detail of this movie was perfect - no doubt it was dangerous to play in. Play in? Better "fight-for-your-life" in. I've experienced some near-dangerous incidents, and am content to live outside of the fray - you guys who feel your manhood raging can have my part.That we have absolutely killed - and continue to do so - irreplaceable areas of this country in undeniable. To be able to view its grandeur on any media is enthralling, but it leaves a bitter taste to realize some do not care about it. Los Angeles, where I live, is a perfect example: it's built-up right into the territories for wild animals, and steadfastly believes humans come before animals. Those are their rightful habitats - we should leave them be just that. Any wonder why coyotes and bears and wolves wander into neighborhoods? They're theirs.In some less threatening way, we all need to experience the lessons to be learned from "Deliverance" - to understand our advancement technologically does not lead to supremacy. I thank all those city-slickers who went out into the wilderness to produce this modern classic, so that it can scare the heck out of me when I watch it. You can have the thrill of danger - I'll stick to the TV. 30-out-of-10.

reviews.review_title: The Nature is not always safe
reviews.content:
Directing: 9
/Acting: 8
/Story: 8
/Production values: 9
/Suspence - Thriller level: 9
/Action: 7
/Mystery - unknown: 8
/Romance level: none
/Comedy elements: none

This film wasn't shot perfectly, it wasn't edited without flaw, and it's hardly an epic adventure. What Deliverance is, is an incredibly brave unsettling work with intensity that gives the viewer a sense of desperation and powerlessness that has yet to be recaptured on screen due to its subject matter. Deliverance should be applauded for its audacity and the will to not conform to any standard studio template of its time. The action flows with the river. Slow and quiet at times, rapid and violent during others. The river becomes a character unto itself, physically challenging these men to their limit, daring them to survive. And surviving means living with the memory of something these four characters will never forget. Envy, hatred, secrecy, deliverance.
Excellent!!, This is real cinema! Excellent comdian,

I give the film high marks for acting and cinematography, but this film did more to feed paranoia about the evils of the American wilderness and its people than any other. It is true that one should not venture into the wilderness without being prepared and know what you're up against, but the great outdoors is not the home of a bunch shiftless, genetically inferior perverts who want to hear strangers squeal like a pig while they're being sexually abused. I would much prefer relying on the hospitality and friendliness of most of the people you meet in the wilderness than on most of the people you might encounter in a big city! As Dirty Harry Callahan used to intone, "A man's got to know his limitations." These guys didn't. They were led by an arrogant hot-shot who took foolish risks from the inception of this fictional adventure, and they ended up just like one would have expected, minus the stereotypical retards and perverts that the countryside is purported to be teeming with according to the writers of this script. The fictionally soon-to-be-no-more Cahulawassee river, which was really the Chattooga river, is still intact as a scenic wilderness area, and will remain so for a very long time into the future. Although a powerful drama from one perspective, Deliverance is a paranoid concoction of fear mongering and disinformation about the realities of the American wilderness and the people who populate it.

reviews.review_title: If We Can Stop People From Marrying Their Siblings.......
reviews.content: Then we put a stop to southern democrats?Is that the story.The story is brutal. The scenery is fantastic and the boy's banjo playing is enthralling.

I'm sorry but if it wasn't for "Dueling Banjos" and the fact that this film introduced " Squeal like a piggie" into common usage. I'd give this film a Zero. It has great potential, with city folks taking a last canoe trip down a soon-to-be- dammed river, and gettin' inta some feudin' with the locals. I love canoes, and was hoping for some decent white water action. Instead I got wooden acting, dull dialogue, a pointless plot and a dirty little scene that got more laughs than shocks when I saw it. Long boring scenes of near drowning took away any chance of my appreciating the progress/nature debate or the concept of civilised man's descent into barbarism when faced with barbaric situations. What a waste of time and talent. They should've had more banjos. I gave it 2.

Deliverance is a 1972 film directed by John Boorman and starring Jogn Voight, Ned Beatty and Burt Reynolds.
Holy Jesus, I somehow came to this movie thinking it was an action/adventure with some comedic elements, maybe because of the name of the film in my native language; so when the "Squeal Like a Pig!" scene came my jaw dropped to the ground.
This is a pretty disturbing movie which is a bit ironic since the cinematography and scenery are really beautiful.
The performances are great, especially John Voight and Ned Beatty, in fact this is my favorite performance from Voight.
The story is gripping and very memourable and the ending is great.
8.2/10

reviews.review_title: What the hell did the cat drag in? This movie sucked!
reviews.content: This movie had absolutely no dramatic effect at all.  If your IQ is even a smidge above room temperature, believe me, you are not going to understand the Appalachian drawl that plagues this pathetic movie.  No music during the "intense" parts, no good acting, no explanation of anything at all.  All this movie does is paint a negative (and well deserved) picture of Southerners.

reviews.review_title: A good movie. That's about it.
reviews.content: Before the hate brigade arrives, it is without question or debate a good movie. Well performed, well written, well executed.But the story is better than the film. Not just the book v movie debate, but the idea and power of the story is stronger than what this film delivered. It's known for dueling banjos and squeal like a pig. Beyond that it's a little empty. Not disappointed, but not a top 100 film.

The writing is atrocious.The directing is atrocious.The acting is atrocious.I'm giving it 3 stars simply because there are worse films.This film has one good scene - the banjo scene.I imagine that and the depiction of southerners is why so many championed it.

After years of hearing about this 'classic', I was expecting something really unique and terrifying. Other than a disgusting and hard to watch rape scene (which is the only reason I figure this film is called 'Deliverance') there isn't another harrowing scene left. I don't know, maybe I was expecting them to be chased by inbred rednecks throughout the film, but instead we get an unrealistic argument that lasts way too long on whether to bury a redneck's body or not and a rather anti-climactic 'fight' scene. Credit must be given where credit is due though. It's a well made movie and the acting is solid. And the dueling banjos scene is memorable. Maybe this film is so well known because it is the first of it's kind, but that doesn't make it the best. I have seen better survival in the wilderness films. I would highly recommend 'The Edge' with Anthony Hopkins and Alec Baldwin. Also 'Wrong Turn' is much more exciting than 'Deliverence' (although there are characters in that movie that are very annoying, but they get theirs).So all in all, it's quite a disappointment. If you want a good John Boorman movie see 'Excalibur' or even the underrated 'Exorcist II: The Heretic' before seeing this one.

reviews.review_title: Ultimate Buddy Film goes very, very wrong
reviews.content: Are we having fun yet? The beatings will continue until morale improves!Deliverance indeed passes the test of time in putting its four protagonists through the test of their lives. The wild, which manifests in the form of the wilderness and the inhabitants of it whom civilization has passed by and disdained, inflicts a savage beating on the four more-or-less everymen who would confront it on its terms--without fully appreciating the awful terms the wilderness can dictate.It's a strong story with a few themes all tied to the struggle of humans to subdue nature, often without fully thinking through the consequences and negative externalities of such actions. It's a very strong cast, who deliver memorable performances. It's also beautifully shot and well-paced, and it leaves the surviving trio without a clear resolution of their predicament and continuing peril. There's a lot to this film beyond its two most memorable scenes, and it certainly deserves the accolades it continues to receive 50 years after its release.

I just saw this movie and i must say it really wasn't that good at all. How some people can say this movie is one the best movies of time is way beyond me. To be blunt about it, it was very boring. I kept waiting for "something" to happen but nothing really ever does. That movie should have been made in about 30 min. The film kept showing them rafting over and over again. VERY VERY REPETITIVE. Thought this movie must have cool ending because of all the hype, but it was a huge letdown. This is one of the most overrated films i have ever seen. The only neat thing about is the atmosphere, and the realism to the film. Other than that it is very sub par. 4/10

reviews.review_title: Just what did happen on the Cahulawassee river?
reviews.content: Before watching this film I had heard a lot about it and certain scenes in the film, but listening wasn't doing it for me so I planned on watching it and wow! Ned Beatty, Ronny Cox, Jon Voight and Burt Reynolds make for an interesting group of individuals who are hell bent on canoing down the Cahulawassee river and the unfortunate series of events that transpires upon them all. The character development takes some time in enveloping the viewer with a better understanding of each person, but eventually you know these guys like they were your friend. The acting, dialogue is very very real, as close to reality as you can get for Hollywood acting. Reynolds character "Lewis" was interesting as a guy who comes off very tough but underneath the manly veneer lies a very soft and broken man (I was impressed with his performance!) Jon Voight seems to be the character thats on the spotlight the most, the unfortunate circumstances that seem to find him at every corner really mold and caste him into a different man at the end (his character transition was excellent). Ned Beatty and Ronny Cox really seem like the silly lunkheads that just like to joke around and don't seem to get too awful serious unless they have too, and they did... I really was amazed at Director Boorman's vision of Dickey's novel, very impressed. You cannot go your whole life without watching this film. I give it eight out of ten stars, extremely impressed.

Boring...a few of my friends said this was a classic. And I should rent it, So I did. Well I guess you could consider it a classic, but It put me to sleep. after watching them paddle down the river for what seems like the whole movie, were treated to like 10 minutes of action (Not including the action that one guy gets) overall I though it was boring and there is hardly any talking in this movie either. Overall 5/10 ZZZZzzzzzz......

reviews.review_title: Still Creepy After All These Years!
reviews.content: Those who are disappointed that this fine film is not more violent, or whatever it is that you think is missing, you probably do not have the attention span necessary to enjoy most films, like Deliverance, that are more subtle in their delivery. The creepy quotient is high in this and I think it is partly because it is driven by the sense of isolation and not necessarily by the level of violence. And who cares if the canoing scenes sometimes don't look altogether realistic. That's hardly the point. One of the other reviewers makes a good point that the scene of the crime will soon be wiped out by flooding, which I think is one of the creepiest aspects of the film. Besides, the actors took some tremendous risks in filming some of those scenes, so I think that kind of criticism is unfair to say the least. Also, this film was nominated for Best Picture in 1972, but the Godfather won that year, so no chance there, although the other pictures nominated probably were not the equal of Deliverance, so if the Godfather had not been in the picture, who knows? It would be difficult to argue against the nominees for Best Actor that year, but perhaps they could have nominated Reynolds for Best Supporting? Of course, then he would have been competing against Pacino, Caan and Duvall from the Godfather, who cancelled each other out and Joel Grey won for "Cabaret" Tough call.

I'm probably pissing off all of the cinema hipsters on here, but I'm watching this in 2022 and I honestly think it's mediocre at best. After reading all of the positive reviews on here, you would think this is the greatest film of all time but it's not even close! Is it bad? No. But it's certainly forgettable and does NOT live up to all of the hype. I honestly think people just praise these films because they were told that they should.

Man I saw this movie a long time ago and it made me sick. You couldn't pay me enough money to watch this movie ever again. I mean the scenery and stuff was nice but what happened to the men made me sick, especially what happened to Ned Beatty. I mean it was sick of the people who made the movie and it should've never been shown at all.

DELIVERANCE stands in my book as a spectacular film. It's so real, you can taste it. Basically, what we have here is a film about human survival. It's a simple story, but it's so effectively made it's unique. Every performer in here delivers an outstanding performance (especially Voight). Boorman's direction is flawless as usual, and Ed O'Neill appears as a policeman in the hospital at the end of the film. 10/10

reviews.review_title: Boring, and I am glad I only paid a buck at Blockbuster to see it
reviews.content: My friends convinced me that this is a classic movie and that I should see it.  After almost falling asleep by what seemed to be a lifetime of footage of them paddling down a river I could barely enjoy any of the rest of the movie.  There was about ten minutes of action in the entire movie.  Well, if you enjoy watching movies with 10 lines of dialogue and documentaries on how not to canoe, then by all means go rent this movie.

reviews.review_title: Not as good as the book
reviews.content: After reading the book, I found the movie to be disappointing.  Many of the best aspects of the novel were left out, including the reason its called Deliverance in the first place.  This is definitely an example of a film adaptation that couldn't live up to the novel.

This is one of the few classic films I would like to see remade. Just for fun viewing of course. As a film the 1972 "Deliverance" can hardly be bettered, but it would be very interesting to see who gets cast...the only alpha male I can think of taking Lewis's role and bow is Hardy, but who gets to squeal, there is the real question...

Four friends decide to embark on a river ride into the mountains of the South. What happens to them during their adventures is what 'Deliverance' is all about.Endlessly compelling and at times extremely uncomfortable to watch, this is one of Boorman's best films by a long way. Solid performances throughout - the guys playing the mountain men were pitch-perfect and utterly believable.It's strong stuff regardless of how old the film is, because of the ideas it conveys - this is a trip into hell and back and will change the lives of those who manage to get out alive.Excellent stuff - recommended.

Finally got to watch this on the 4th day of 4th month, 20+20 = 4.
Was that a sign of bad luck, as Asians tend to believe ?Certainly for the protagonists of this cult classic.. and also for me as a viewer.. the movie ran dry quickly due to its lengthy water scenes during which not much happens.It has its good moments of tension, mystic and suspense, and one can draw several morals from it.Highly watchable, dont expect a masterpiece though.

reviews.review_title: Good, but not as good as it was
reviews.content: I don't know about anyone else, but I find a lot of 70s movies don't really hold up when viewed through modern eyes.  Deliverance has one foot in this camp.  When I saw it in 1978 I thought it was genuinely disturbing, and kept me on the edge of my seat.  Watching it last night, for the first time since then, I enjoyed it, but not as much as I was expecting.Some parts just didn't ring true.  After Burt Reynolds shoots the hillbilly, Ned Beatty makes a very half hearted attempt to grab the dead man, the others restrain him, and not a word is spoken.  That didn't seem to work for me.  Then why did John Voight climb the cliff to kill the hillbilly?  They weren't even sure that Ronny Cox had been shot.  Just get in the canoe and scarper who heaven's sake.  If the hillbilly had been trying to get them he could have picked them off as they sat about, and Voight would have been very vulnerable half way up a cliff.That said, it is still an iconic film.  If you are ever in some spooky woods in the middle of nowhere just say "deliverance territory" and everyone knows what you mean.  That, I suppose, is a test of a good film after all.

reviews.review_title: Deliverance is a well made and disturbing thriller. Although I'm not sure what its point is.
reviews.content: Deliverance is about 4 men who go canoing on a river that is soon to be flooded out. All 4 seem to be trying in their own way to get in touch with nature, especially the macho and strong-willed Lewis (Reynolds). Along the way they encounter tragedy and horrid adventure in the form of rape, murder, and survival as they try to get out alive.Deliverance is well written and acted. It is also contains a disturbing, but terrifyingly memorable, rape scene. The film induces genuine panic, terror, and somewhat more-or-less believable characters. It starts off slow but once the tension accumulates, Deliverance never looks back once.Burt Reynolds and Jon Voight may be at their finest here as two harrowed and injured men trying their hardest to survive. Ned Beatty and Ronny Cox are also excellent as two of the four friends that are each either physically or mentally tortured, or both. For the side characters the filmmakers decided to use town locals from where Deliverance was shot. This injects a huge touch of realism and naturality into the movie, making it all more scarily believable.Now for the one and only flaw of Deliverance: It never "delivers" a clear message or statement of what it's trying to convey to us. Is it supposed to be about masculinity vs. the wilderness, living with the regret of murder, or is it about survival. Personally I believe the movie is about the human survival instinct, and also how far one may go to cover up a past mistake that could severely detriment their life. But who the hell knows, I guess it's all up to the viewer to decide what message they got out of the film.Overall Deliverance was a strong and powerful film, although I was never truly moved by it. It is very adventurous and heart stopping at times, and of course well acted and written. I give Deliverance a 3 out of 4.

Well yeah... There are more than couple of problems in the "continuity" section...Butb it's okay, I can live with them! - The story itself is horrifically monstrous and thus good!Burt Reynolds makes in my opinion the best role of his entire career - and look at Jon Voight after about 75 minutes: he looks like a young Johnny Depp!

I feel this represents the apex of Ned Beatty's long and storied acting career. He was absolutely magical in this film. His interpretation of a white, middle-class weekend camper getting man-raped brought a tear to my eye and served as my inspiration to play Willie Loman in my high school production of "Death of a Salesman."

reviews.review_title: When canoeing, it is wise to keep EVERYTHING watertight.
reviews.content: This film holds up surprisingly well today, and is still worthwhile as pure cinema, and not just for the scene that has pervaded popular culture. The cast is excellent (though Burt Reynolds struggles at times), the story simple and compelling, the photography and atmosphere superb, and the script lean and fast-paced. (Having said all this, however, allow me to be pretentious for a second and say that, yes, the book IS better than the movie.) This film is highly recommendable for anyone aged 16 and up.

Not sure if it is the older style movies that had to follow the narrative with no special effects, I found this a little on the sleepy side. The isle of suspense was missing although at specific scenes you wonder if they would survive. While the acting was good, I found that there was a lot of directed emotion and the dramatic scenes were not realistic. I was left with disappointment at the end as there was no real closure of the story of the heartache 4 people experienced together.

reviews.review_title: Try to conceive of a movie based on the whitest stereotypes you can think of and wahlah you have this!
reviews.content: I thought to myself originally that this was like broke back mountain without the homosexuality, it appears I spoke too soon. There was rushing in this film rushing to get to the destination and rushing to scram and I was glad that this movie was as short as it was because I was rushing to get through it!The moral of the story boys and girls is that you should make sure to heed warnings. It has action, it has drama, it has horror and this movie was really a movie of it's time. The kind of movie you better pay very close attention to because after it's through you won't want to have it as a favorite or be able to stomach watching it over & over again. It's great to be able to say I watched it. This movie is 18 yrs. older than me.

A canoe trip down the river. It is just fun and games, until the suspense starts. And the suspense is so intense that many have thought the Deliverance is a horror movie, even it has not any supernatural elements.
Has this film been a model for hundreds of terror movies, where a group of teenagers go to spend a weekend in a cabin?
Martin Heidegger said that the real art opens the reality. The directors and film stars disappear and you are observing the being as it is. Hence, with strong presence of nature and torturous plot Deliverance does not feel a movie at all.
I dropped one star for that famous and disgusting scene that everyone knows.
The book also recommendated.

A critically-acclaimed drama from 1972 that was ahead of its time, Deliverance shows the tragic results of trying to reason with Donald Trump supporters. Stars Burt Reynolds and Jon Voight as sane people from civilization, who have to make difficult decisions about their own survival; decisions that are much tougher and more dangerous than the ones we will all have to make during the 2016 family holidays. The film doesn't hold back - there are some truly shocking scenes in Deliverance, perhaps more shocking even than watching a 2016 presidential debate or campaign speech. This film is well worth watching, and will provide a welcome escape from the drama engulfing all our lives. Sort of. Well, at least the scenery is different.

This movie is a true classic. It shocked all of us when it came out (I was 15 years old).What could have been a boring movie turned into an intense drama.One of my all time favorite scenes is from this movie!(Without giving away any more), the scene is when Burt's character is slowly pulling back an arrow in his bow. I have always loved his beautiful arms and "manliness," and the circumstances that make it a classic moment.Anyway, the movie watcher is pulled 100% into this scene. It felt like a lot of time passes from the time he puts the arrow in and eventually releases it. However, you will never see the whole scene on public TV. They edit the ___ out of that scene.See this movie on tape or DVD. It really pushes boundaries and is amazing.

reviews.review_title: Been wanting to go on a canoeing trip for a while
reviews.content: What initially seems like a fairly serious premise, John Boorman does a fantastic job of creating what I would consider to the best summer comedy of 1972. Three big city hotshots and one unlikable fat man decide to embark on a coming-of-age canoe trip in some shithole in the backwoods of America and encounter a bunch of zany characters who give our heroes a rich lesson in the culture and traditions of a lesser known area of world. Such encounters involve a banjo lesson from a child of the local gifted and talented school and a game of shotgun hide and go seek, which Jon Voight wins albeit unconvincingly taking advantage of a gentleman who appears to not be completely in control of his faculties. Speaking of hiding things, there is a great wrestling scene between two men, which really encapsulates the essence of masculinity and human triumph, who decide to sort out their stark contrasts in socioeconomic status and cultural beliefs like true men, Mano a Mano. Heartwarming stuff guys.

reviews.review_title: Great acting, good movie, perfect hillbillies
reviews.content: I like this movie and would recommend anyone who hasn't seen it to watch it.The acting in the movie is great. Reynolds, Voight and Beatty all do an excellent job here. I must say though the actors who played the Red necks were outstanding. Their performance as Appalachian hillbillies are one of the most realistic and accurate portrayal of Appalachian hill folk ever put on film. I couldn't even tell whether their acting was incredibly great or if they were actual hicks being filmed in their natural habitat. I figure it must have been their acting skills since it would be incredibly hard to get real rednecks to read and memorize their lines.

An extraordinary movie made by men for real men.This movie is NOT some kind of movie that will get appreciation from highly sensitive freaks of today who have no idea what the real masculine mentality is."Deliverance" exceptionally depicts the situation when real men have to deal with an unusual trouble when their dignity and survival are tested.The cast, the story, and the cinematography are perfect "10".

Plot: Four men go on a canoeing trip.
