As they travel down the river, they wage war against two sadistic hillbillies, whose simple-minded and criminally stereotypical goals are best unmentioned in this review. Frankly, the entirety of the film is nothing more than fluff to embellish around a single disturbing act.  The morals surrounding the characters' actions, concerning death and the law, are addressed minimally and tossed aside after five minutes of trite dialogue.  This movie is incomplete in every aspect and should be branded as no less than unsatisfying and bizarre.Theme: Nature is fundamentally incompatible with "The System."  Wilderness is best left undisturbed.

The film years 1971 to 1972 were pretty raw at the movies.  The ratings code of 1968 ("R," "X") was a few years old, sex, violence, nudity, language were all allowed in ways like never before, and for some reason (maybe sex plus violence)rape movies were all the rage.  But it was usually women getting raped:  Kubrick's "A Clockwork Orange," Siegel's "Dirty Harry," Peckinpah's "Straw Dogs," Hitchcock's "Frenzy."Then, along came "Deliverance," and it was time for the men to get the willies, literally.  I suspect that more than a few women enjoyed seeing the tables turned,. The male rape scene is what put "Deliverance" on the map in 1972, along with, oddly enough, a delightful instrumental duet called "Duelling Banjos" that was a Top Forty hit on the radio! (In the movie, this duet comes early, and is haunting: one player is a decidedly scary looking, silent backwoods boy.)In many ways, "Deliverance" was simply a modern outdoor adventure tale. Four suburban males (macho Burt Reynolds and three more soft fellows) take a canoe trip down a desolate Georgia river and must survive.   City boys lost in the wilderness.  About all audiences were expecting was a rapids ride, but thanks to that terrifying sexual encounter with some inbred hillbilly men, "Deliverance" was the an old-time adventure in the sexually explicit, realistically violent manner of the early 70's. They certainly don't make them like this anymore.P.S.  Here's a question: given what happens to each of the four heroes, which one would you want to be?

reviews.review_title: The power of 'squeal like a pig.'
reviews.content: Finally sat down and watched Deliverance for the first time after years of using it for fodder for jokes. Even discounting the best known scenes, what a particularly awful movie. With its wooden acting and poor writing, if it didn't have the one scene everyone knows (yeah, you know the one), I think that it would have slipped completely into obscurity. Why sink Drew's body after dragging it down river? Why sink the hunter's body where you not only you lost all your equipment (like the other canoe) but you knowingly dropped your entire wallet? Did they really have to tape a mass of chewed on spam to Burt Reynolds' leg to show that he had broken it? Complete garbage, and I'll never get that hour and a half of my life back.

i started to watch this some time ago i was expecting a masterpeice but i got a disapointment the story was a bit dull and boring when i got to the end i was expecting more from this film . overated sould be kicked out of the top 250 films now and be replaced by something worthy of the word masterpice like casino. overated a bore

No question, James Dickey's novella put to film is a masterpiece. The four characters in the film are, of course, the composite of the main protagonist played by the young John Voight. I frequently embark on canoe trips and the music and visual imagery of this film intrudes into the experience. James Dickey's in a cameo performance as the incredulous southern sheriff is a delight.

reviews.review_title: This movie made me want to squeal like a pig. Squeal Ned, Squeal.
reviews.content: NOTE: This review is probably not worth reading if you're acutally interested in honest insight into the movie.  But it might be funny, but it might not be that either. The first time I saw this movie, I wanted to squeal like a pig.  I'm sorry but the scene in which ned beaty gets ass raped is simply wrong in so many ways.  Wrong wrong wrong wrong wrong.  I mean come on, who wants to see that? seriously?  Anyway, dispite some flaws in early seventies cinematography, and at times slow pacing, this film still manages to hold some attention.  This film is able to make a comment about the lifestyle of impoverished southern mountin folk, while still being able to capture burt reynolds in a tight plastic wetsuit.  I don't really understand what all the hype is about really.  The actors were able to portray somewhat realistic characters which made me less apethic than such river films as the river wild, and tom and huck.  Let's be honest, this review itself is terrible, and merely a comment on the fact that this film did not interest me, and if your young and looking for a moive to rent, don't rent this one.  Rent Jackie Chan's who am I? if only to repeat the phrase Who am I to your friends for hours on end.

When I was 16 back in '72 my pals and I heard this was the 'must see' movie of the year--so we went--and I was less than impressed. But fifty years of hype and accolades for this one made me wonder if I'd really missed something at that age that I'd appreciate now. On re-view that is not the case. The picture suffers from a poor, screenplay that moves too slow at times, too cliche' at other times, and just nonsensically most of the time. The yelling and constant pseudo-pickering between the characters makes it hard to swallow they'd ever plan a coffee shop meeting together, let alone an extended camping trip. At every turn I found myself thinking, "You've got to be kidding me!" This doesn't even work as a period piece other than to note many films in the early 70s seemed to feature peculiar if not inappropriate laughter at times by the protagonists that has thankfully disappeared from Hollywood since. Skip.

Deliverance was a smash hit at the time and still travels well but the film makers made some mistakes that caused the deaths of several people who perhaps tried the stunts in this movie.First, river runners would never take canoes down a river like this. You would take whitewater rafts or kayaks built for the rapids. Running a difficult river takes skill acquired by training, which these characters did not have.Second, river running takes advanced planning and once on the river, scouting the rapids. River runners have to scout the tough rapids ahead of them before they run them. If the rapids are too difficult or unrunnable, the water craft have to be lined down the rapids with ropes.Third, river runners need a shuttle waiting for them at the end of the trip to return them to their vehicles or they need people to shuttle their vehicles to the landing. You must have the utmost trust in the shuttle drivers and pay them well.Watch Deliverance for the drama and suspense; watch The River Wild for white water realism.

Someone must be kidding??? For two hours I was watching four unsympathetic, hysterical nutcases (actually three because at least Burt Reynolds shows some signs of masculinity), who set out for a suicidal voyage on a river where only a complete idiot would go. That the biggest nut of them dies and I don't have to listen to his annoying yelling is a very weak relief. Eventually, the remaining trio buries a rifle (to prevent the possibility that they could defend themselves) and another of them shoots himself with his own arrow (which gets the entire film somewhere to the proximity of the Naked Gun series). A pretty repulsive spectacle.

Original and action packed, you want it to last longer just like The Shawshank Redemption... there is tension, new sights, hillbillies like Joe Machin's base and of course squealing love making West Virginia style.

reviews.review_title: Not as good as I remembered it.
reviews.content: This is one of those classic movies from when I was younger that I remembered as very thrilling, well-acted and with with some disturbing scenes. The banjo scene is still a masterpiece. This movie has always popped-up in my mind when I've been out hiking and such things, kind of like the movie Jaws always pops up in people's heads when they're out on the water.I recently watched this with my 16 year old son (in 2022), after having hyped it from what I remembered it to be. The first half of the movie is still entertaining with some classic scenes, but I remembered it to be much more. Not very much actually happened after the first half, so it felt quite slow to be honest.My son mentioned "this could have been done as a Youtube video today" referring to the production quality back in the days. It is still a good story, but not at all as exciting as I remembered it. I believe we are so used to long well-produced streaming series today that these old movies really can't compete with what's being produced today.

I'm surprised at the amount of positive reviews for this one. It's an older movie, 1970s; the scenes are not scary at all, you don't see them falling off from huge waterfalls...they don't seem scared, and you're scared for them. You can see it's actors acting...they pretend they're exhausted at the end, rowing to the shore...the whole movie is set in the same environment...some small river, except for the first few minutes of the beginning and end. People give exaggerated credit to older and badly-made movies, and to independent and cheap movies...I don't; what is good is good, and what isn't isn't - this wasn't.Yeah, there's the rape scene in the middle of the movie...nothing special. There's the kid playing the banjo in the beginning, but I didn't care too much for it.It's as if anyone could have made this film himself. The River Wild seemed realer and scarier, not to mention it had better acting...I saw it when I was much younger, could really be as bad, tho, now. It's a movie starring Meryl Streep, and not as old. I don't have a problem with old movies, but I'm not a fan of badly-made 1970s movies.Skip this one.

This movie was spine-chilling at times, yet you felt like you were really there.  Basically, four guys went canoing for the adventure.  But, it ended up being their worst nightmares.  Even though Burt didn't get the biggest part :(, it was great.  You felt like you really knew these people, it was sooo real.  If you haven't seen this movie, I suggest you rent or buy it now!!  I give it 10/10.

....I was advised not to shout so i must just start by saying this film was particularly awful because it really has no meaning, and the characters are just wafty and weak. I mean, the river was nice to look at but i was expecting to watch an actual film. That really was the absolute highlight. The rape seen was good because it was freaky and i did sit up a bit and stop eating my crisps. Spoiler - Four men in a river.
Great movie. Nice story, interesting characters, beautiful scenery... Maybe a bit over extended, it would have worked even better without the last 15 minutes or so...

reviews.review_title: Great scenery, but long, boring story and wooden acting make this movie hugely overrated!
reviews.content: Dumb guys who sell insurance go on a canoe trip. With no clue where they are, clueless in what they are doing. They involve local strangers who look barely human after generations of inbreeding, they get hunted, and one raped because they were too stupid to leave crazy people alone. The river kills Drew, Lewis (Burt) nearly dies, and if he only died for real in 1972 then the cinematic world would be better for it. The hillbillies try to kill them all themselves, but the canoe dummies manage to kill two of them. It's a depressingly creepy town, so bad I had to wonder why anyone went to the lengths they did to try and save anything in it. The survivors evade the law (which again seems out of place where they are), go home and cry, end of story. Altogether it's twice as long as the story requires, an extremely depressing story, and at least two hours which would be better spent soaking your head in the toilet, or running around naked in the woods while squealing like a pig. SQUEEEEEAL!!! Did I mention the acting was terrible? I know this was a horror movie, but the acting in itself was the most harrowing part of it all, save the hillbillies who deserve Oscars for convincing portrayal of craziness. The very worst of the acting, and ranking among the worst I've seen anywhere was between Reynolds and Voight.The only worthwhile scene in this whole movie was the duet of Drew's guitar with Creepy, Dead-Eyed Hillbilly's banjo in Dueling Banjos. I'm not a bluegrass fan, but that song can be a lot of fun! Points given only for scenery and creative creepiness of town and locals.

reviews.review_title: Maybe next time they will play golf..........*SPOILERS*
reviews.content: This is a very interesting piece of 70's cinema.  I have heard so much about this movie that was created 2 years before I was born.  Being a fan of the horror genre you would think that this movie would have crossed my path, cause let's face it folks.  This is a horror film. What could be more frightening than being lost, isolated, and hunted.  The movie opens with our 4  city folks heading for a weekend jaunt to an unspoiled river that won't exsist in a few weeks. It is being dammed to provide power to the ever growing Atlanta.  Knowing ahead of time what was coming, I had a hard time sympathizing with these four guys.  Lewis, Bobby, and Ed were rude to the locals of this "inbred" mountain town. The only redeeming member was Drew who decides to have an impromptu guitar/banjo jam with a very creepy but talented boy. These guys were kind of cocky and other than Lewis I wasn't sure why they came along for such a trip.  Commence rafting, and camping and then some more rafting.  Cue the infamous "Squeal" scene.  I didn't quite understand the dynamic here.  These 2 grown men allow themselves to be completely overpowered, without so much as a fight, a kick, a punch.....nothing.  The most pathetic part of Ned Beatty's rape sequence is watching him try to crawl up the hill while the mountain man is grabbing on to his briefs like some sort of harness.  Cue Bert Reynolds and his bow, saving Ed, Bobby and this movie from an X rating. Now here is another part I had trouble understanding.  If I was in this group and this series of events just occured to me or my friends.  I would have abosolutely no moral dilema with offing this cretin and getting the hell out of Dodge!  But the guys fight amoungst themselves over the moral dilema of having just killed a man. Nevermind that the man was gonna rape and probably kill 2 men. Drew, the guitar plucker, thinks they should take the high road and let the law handle things.  Thank goodness cooler heads prevailed and the guys decide burial was the right way to go.  How perfect!! This place will be under several feet of water in a few days.  The rest of the film consists of these guys trying to escape from an enemy that might not even be there. This leads to many injuries, twists, turns etc...... See it for yourself.  Deliverance is a thought provoking movie.  I was amazed to realize how many early 80's camp/horror movies stole from this one.

Well i hate to put a dampner on things but..it wasn't that good. Ok, it was good, just not THAT good. I'd heard a lot about it, it's supposed to be a classic, so i was quite disappointed. I found the acting to be somewhat questionable, and as for the rape scene,well, it didn't take him long to get over it. I found each of the main characters slightly annoying, Reynold's character especially, and how many times in the film does Voight have to shout 'Lewis!'? the beginning was exceedingly slow and boring (i made some friends watch it with me and felt slightly embarrassed by it's dullness), and the end is absurd, why did Voight climb the cliff, kill an innocent guy, then climb down? and after all that, how did they get away with it??? that's not to say i hate it, it just wasn't as good as everyone makes it sound.

Deliverance is a movie about four business men that embark on a journey down a river through backwoods Appalachia. The men decide to go on a canoing trip before the river and surrounding countryside are buried under a massive lake being formed for the creation of a new power station. The men cross paths with two hillbillies from the backwoods and the canoing trip soon turns from a fun trip to a nightmare of survival. Lewis sees Bobby in the woods being humiliated and sodomized by one of the hillbillies. He takes matters into his own hands and shoots and kills the man with a bow and arrow. The men then face a decision on whether to call the authorities or bury the man in the countryside that will soon be covered in water. After a vote the men decide to bury the man and continue down river to get to their cars that are waiting for them. On their adventure down stream Drew decides not to wear his life jacket and falls into the river at some rough rapids. This causes his boat to collide with the other boat and all four men end up in the water. Lewis breaks his leg and convinces Bobby and Ed that Drew was shot by the hillbilly. This provokes Ed to climb the gorge and kill the other hillbilly. The three men make it to their cars and are questioned by the authorities. The men are not charged and they go their own ways. I think that this movie raises some questions on what exactly happened to Drew. I question if the hillbilly actually shot Drew or if he could not face what had happened on the river. It also makes you wonder why he would not wear his life jacket knowing that there had been rough rapids and they would probably face more.

This is truly a great movie. well made as you can see by the posts. a great movie will not answer all your questions but create questions for us to ponder for 32 years and counting. we may never know. here is what i think.Drew either had a heart attack or jumped. i think he committed suicide. the hunter that was killed by ed was not "the" toothless hillbilly. why would he have put his false teeth in? why would the sheriff ask about the missing hunter at the end. and yes that is Ed O'neill as the hospital room cop.now i have to watch it again to prove to myself.

I think this movie is one of those that tends to guide you to see, hear, or feel what it wants you too. I sat on a Sunday afternoon, with the flu, and watched this. I didn't pay that much attention at first but then I started to hear sounds in the background of the movie that "told" me to pay more attention. In the first few scenes you could really care less about watching, but if you listen very carefully the background sounds draw you in.The center of the movie is kind of freaky, if you listen. The end of the movie was "blah" but I would still rate it a good 8 if not 9 (just for the freakiness). I think everyone who thinks of themselves as a "movie buff" should watch this, maybe with eyes closed to listen to what the movie has to say.

'We're gonna rape this land, we're gonna rape it' Its Stand By Me for grown ups. Deliverance contains something simplistic that never fails to shock, excite and horrify altogether. Yet even since 1972 it is a testament to the golden oldies that never diminish from the audience's mind. It is very fast paced and aggressive from the start, something you can watch in an hour and a half, yet still the naturalistic approach of director John Boorman remains true to the original story; it is not over sensationalised with music or flimsy acting, or under achieved in any way. It is an account of the terrors that lurk in the backwater, small country towns where strangers are neglected, threatened, terrorised. Much of the movies' story balances on the horrific male rape scene; perpetuated with slow burning use of editing that builds up the tension to danger levels. It's a modern classic; the year of Clockwork Orange; ultra violence at it's best when it seems to come true. Yet still, Deliverance remains even after the land is gone beneath the raging waters.

Having read many positive reviews on this film I was looking forward to seeing it. Unfortunately I was really quite disappointed with what I saw.Firstly I thought it moved far too slowly. If you are going to make an action film that moves this slowly then make sure that your characters are interesting enough to carry the viewers attention. This film could really have explored it's characters much more than it did - there were lots of opportunities to find out what these guys thought about life and their current predicament but I never found anything out about these guys other than background details.Secondly the hillbillies were portrayed as stupid and/or bad and nothing else. They were just cardboard stereotypes, surely they could have been shown to have a few more facets to their character. Again it would have made the story more interesting.Thirdly Burt Reynolds acting was completely over the top in a superhero type way. I know he was supposed to play the macho outdoor type but when I saw him on the screen I kept on thinking of Adam West as Batman in the TV series. At least Adam West can use the excuse that he was playing a real superhero.The best bit for me was the duelling Banjos scene. As someone who enjoys Bluegrass I really enjoyed listening to the guitar and banjo players playing together. The kid was playing so fast I'm sure I saw sparks coming off his Banjo!

The only reason I comment on "Deliverance" is to recommend that viewers search out a copy of Henry Hart's biography of James Dickey, "The World as a Lie," in order to read fascinating sections that discuss the background of Dickey's book and the making of the movie.  It will help dispel a bunch of the myths and legends that have arisen surrounding the events of the book and film -- particularly the rape scene, which has no factual basis to support those who judge certain regions of the U.S. and those regions' peoples based entirely on viewing this film.

An action movie usually doesn't include complex subjects and emotions: this one does. With ongoing character development, there's never a dull moment, even though you're basically on the edge of your seat the entire time. Each man's character is well formed and very different from other characters. Their wildlife journey turns into something none of the men expect. Each man responds differently to every event and experience and the viewer sees it all. The river, in every way, is an unexpected journey I saw from several viewpoints. It's a ride I'll never forget. There's no taking sides, truth or closure. The film title is perfect. The word is heavy with meaning in Deliverance.

I watched this on DVD with high expectations. 'The duelling banjos' tune retrieved from the back of my mind. As I sat back to watch I was immediately hit with how dated the film was.The scenery was great and when they get up into the wilderness to begin their journey and they meet the local boy with the Banjo that tune imediately gets into your mind. Unfortunately for me it is soon after this that the story becomes a little dull. Whilst the story was great back in the seventies it seems to have lost some of its appeal over the last few years. The river scenes make the film but the rapids seemed to be a little tame compared to how I remember them first time round. There is a certain rough quality to the film that makes it worth seeing at least once. The commentary on the DVD is worth watching just to understand how they approached filming in such a remarkable location.

reviews.review_title: Kinda good disturbing thriller, but not the masterpiece everone else sees.
reviews.content: I can say for a fact that this movie is good. It kept me intrigued, wondering how the 4 men was going to be affected by this turbulent canoe vacation. BUT....it's not all that. Usually i tell people the good / great movies does start kind of slow and then somewhere in the middle turns up as far as the knob go, but this movie started a little too slow. Took a while for the "action" to happen, and i wouldn't say it's that action packed. But it did do a good job of putting on display of how much human nature is willing to do for survival. This movie took a dark turn, and it was worth it. Maybe not almost 2 hours worth it, but worth it nonetheless. Really if i had to give an exact rating it would be like a 6.2-6.3/10.

I'm so disappointed with this "classic" movie. I guess during the actors early career, their acting were terrible. Classic film with all star cast does not equate to an excellent film. I'm shocked this movie receive an Oscar nomination.
This movie is amazing.. Iam nt much fan of old movies, but this one really made me a classic one.

reviews.review_title: Rather slow and not as disturbing as I'd been led to believe.
reviews.content: The acting is good. The cinematography is good. The scenery is spectacular and the script passes muster. But "Deliverance" is not the classic that I had been expecting. It seems to me that only the surface of all the various emotions were dealt with and scenes such as the aftermath of the rape and the argument about what to do with the body were glossed over incredibly quickly. As for the actual rape scene itself... well, I reckon that the main reason so many people find this so disturbing is because they're not used to such scenes involving a man. Society seems to have become horribly de-sensitised to the idea of women being raped because it happens, and is portrayed in the media, so often. When it happens to a man everyone throws back their heads and howls in horror, as if it were somehow worse than female rape.I'd say by all means watch this film, it is certainly worth one viewing at least. But if you want to see a good example of the sickening horror of what inbreeding can do (not that I'm saying this was the main theme of "Deliverance) then watch the episode of "The X-Files" that deals with the subject. Now that really is truly, horrifically disturbing.
Beautiful and evocativeA manly movie when city clickers take the chest hair out and go kayaking in the mountains of West Virginia. Then adventure and some sex ensues.Brilliant and fun.

I have just come across the movie and I have watched it a few times over as it is really fascinating. As the plot suggests, even though it is fictional, none of the six characters involved would live to talk about what happened. Three of them died in the course of the events, and the remaining three would keep their mouth shut for the fear of legal consequences, so there really is no one to tell the story. Who is the storyteller then? The only sound candidate is Ed as the only one who witnessed all the events in the story.

reviews.review_title: ALL of the positive reviews are true,BUT:
reviews.content: All of the good reviews of this movie are quite valid, but I have one particular problem with it. Before I get into that, I'll say that I avoided watching this movie for many years, for a couple of reasons. I heard some comedian make fun of Ned Beatty's famous rape scene, and I hated to see that. I got to meet Ned when he was at actors theater, in Louisville. I had seen him do such a beautiful performance in death of a salesman (as the salesman), that I went back and saw it a second time. And later got a chance to talk to him. So I have followed his career closely , except for this movie. I had seen just the banjo, guitar, duet scene, many years ago on TV, and I thought the banjo boy was so creepy, I didn't want to see anymore at the time. But, tonight it was on Turner and I watched the whole thing, fast forwarding through the guitar banjo duet. And I loved it! Except for one huge problem: the Southern accents by these Hollywood actors are terrible! I heard an explanation of this some years back: there's one guy who's been teaching Southern accents to movie stars, and he teaches them wrong! He teaches the Charleston, South Carolina, accent as being the right one for the whole south. That's the one where they drop the R's , like "Cone heah! Ya heah me, gull?!" They are terribly distracting for someone who has an ear out for it!

reviews.review_title: You Will Not Forget This One Actually
reviews.content: A bunch of city slickers and a democrat fatso show up in true blue America and are confronted by the power and might of the Republican Americana. The true Americans own the land and do not welcome the intruders with their superior arrogance and attitude.The raft will not be having a smooth journey and you will be entertained.

reviews.review_title: Still scary, after all these years
reviews.content: Never a huge Burt Reynolds fan, I believe he gives a spot on performance here as a tough city man trying to stamp his mark on nature. Jon Voight gives his usual great value. Were this film to be made in the 21st Century, it would doubtless be over-produced, cost a fortune and be all the worse for it. This film is one of a good number of examples of the fact that a tense, disturbing story does not need a huge budget. Naturally, the film is now dated in many ways but the period feel adds to its appeal now and the events could occur as easily today as in their early 70s depiction. The duelling banjos tune is hauntingly used throughout the picture and skillfully brought into the story early on in the drama. If you haven't watched this movie for a while, take the opportunity when it arises and enjoy the performances and the tale.

reviews.review_title: Not bad, not so great either.
reviews.content:
Deliverance doesn't really deserve its cult status. The scenario has little close to nothing to say, the acting is fine, the directing is maybe just above average. Overall better than most B movies, but not by much.
I guess it went down in history thanks to the two infamous scenes : the banjo duet (awesome indeed) and the shocking scene that sets everything in motion (who can only appeal to those hungry for shock value in order to satisfy their inner bully - i. e. teenagers).
Everything else is subpar and produces more confusion than emotion. Alpha-male Burt Reynolds and his gay jacket bring comic relief, but I'm not sure that was intentional.

reviews.review_title: Four men decide to canoe down a river to prove their manhood.
reviews.content: John Boorman's Deliverance is one of the best films of the 1970s. It was nominated for three Oscars including Best Picture. Burt Reynolds, who missed out on an Oscar nomination because of his nearly nude poster in a popular magazine, plays Lewis. He is the macho man in the group. He attempts to lead men in an unforgettable canoe trip. Jon Voight is equally good as a business man who attempts to prove his manhood. Ned Beatty is outstanding and symbolizes man's rape of nature. Ronny Cox is the man who cannot cope with the guilt of the murdered Mountain Man. Herbert Cowboy Coward is perfectly cast as the Toothless Man. Vilmos Zsigmond's cinematography is second to none.
The movie is very redneck and ridiculous at the beginning. good acting i guess. very dramatic trust me. dislike this movie very much. don't get why ppl like it. never watching again

reviews.review_title: I was shocked at how old this movie was.
reviews.content: Deliverance, staring John Voight and Burt Reynolds, was a very entertaining movie to watch. There is a lot to like about this film. It really draws you into the story, as four men from the city decide to venture down the Cahulawassee River before the government tampers with it. Not too long into their journey, does their nature trip turn into a vicious fight for survival. What was great about this film was the editing. It was paced very good as director John Boorman really let his scenes play out perfectly. To a viewer who knows nothing about this film, there are a bunch of surprises in place that will really make them squirm in their seat. The film looked fantastic, to the point that its really hard to believe how dated this film actually is. It's thirty six year old movie that looks like something that could be aired in theaters today. There is though, a few things that I didn't like. It's hard to determine if the character Lewis was supposed to be that strange and awkward or if Burt Reynolds just did a horrible job in his role. He's the cool guy of the group, who knows how to survive in the wilderness, who knows how to handle every situation perfectly. However at times he just seemed like an idiot, who has absolutely no idea what he's doing or talking about. It's easier to say that Reynolds botched up his role, being that he was never really considered that great of an actor. John Voigt, on the other hand, was superb. With the exception of the scenes where he's talking to himself on the mountain, he does an amazing job as the character everyone's supposed to relate to and feel for. I felt this movie was enjoyable ALMOST the whole way through. It could have ended a good twenty minutes before it did. Overall though, I really liked it.

It just wasn't particularly good for me. I rate a movie based on whether it can evoke an emotional reaction from me. Many people seem to think that this movie is a masterpiece or some piece of art. If so, then I'll stick with the movies I like. It just wasn't for me. What was I supposed to learn? That the rural South is dangerous sometimes? That it's different from more urban areas? Isn't that much already obvious? I just didn't enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: Can you squeal like a pig?
reviews.content: Even though this is an extremely good movie, and I can understand people giving it top score, I have to say I was disappointed at the end of the movie. It just ends too soon, they could have made that film 10 times more scarier by just making it 30 minutes longer. Anyhow, I would advise those who enjoyed Blair Witch Project and the Haunting to see this movie. I'm pretty sure you will like it.
Just Not even a good movie, terrible storyline, bad acting! Just really no point to have ever been made.. lol

I saw this movie for the first time last night.  All I can say was it was completely disturbing and full of un-necessary brutality.  The male rape scene made me sick to my stomach, and if there is anyone out there who is considering to watch this film and you're easily grossed out...do yourself a favor--watch something else!  I don't think I'll ever want to go camping again after this movie!!!

reviews.review_title: Mans struggle against man, nature, and himself.
reviews.content:
I watched "Deliverance" with much anticipation, and when it was over, I was left feeling unsatisfyed, confused, and disturbed. There's no doubt that the "squeal like a pig scean" sticks out in my mind like a sore thumb. But now, I have to think about the movie as a whole to truly appritiate it.
It starts out with  four city boys looking for adventure by taking a canoe trip in hillbilly country. The group is lead by Lewis,(Reynolds) a wanna be "Tarzan", as Bobby would put it, and is also suppost to serve as the eye candy for the ladies. Bobby,(Beatty) is  undoubtedly the stuck up one of the group, who looks as though he's dressed to go to a golf course, rather than a rigorus weekend canoe trip in the middle of nowhere. Ed, (Voight) is the soft spoken follower of Lewis, but is eventually shoved into the role of the hero. Drew,(Cox) is the gentle guitar player, who takes part in the famous "Dueling Banjos" scean. But when push comes to shove, he is also the only character with any morels when it comes time for the men to make a decisio n that will change their lives forever.It starts out innocent enough for the men, a day of canoeing, fishing, and a night of drinking and sleeping on the ground in tents. As morning breaks, Ed trys his hand at hunting, but it's easy to see by the shaking of his hands, that he doesn't have the heart to kill even a deer. This will become a key point in the movie later, as Ed is forced into a similair situation, that could end or save his life.After a brief separation, one of the characters is raped by a local hunter, and the four men are reduced to animals, digging furiously with their hands to bury the man who was killed by them, clearly in self defence. But after one of their own is killed, one lie quickly snowballs into another. By the end, you can see that even though 3 out of the 4 city boys survived their horrible experience,it will haunt them for the rest of their lives, and none of them will ever recieve deliverance from it.5/5 stars for wonderful acting, story line, and for seeing Burt Reynolds cry like a baby.

reviews.review_title: New Movie Starring the Mountain Men from Deliverance
reviews.content: October 16th, 2007 - The new movie "Ghost Town" will star Herbert Cowboy Coward and Bill McKinney. This film brings Deliverance mountain men back to screen for the first time since Deliverance in 1972. 33 years after their performance, Maxin Magazine voted them the number one movie villains of all time and AFI has voted Deliverance to be number 15 in all time favorite Thrillers. Ghost Town story was written by Dean Teaster and DJ Perry as an Appalachain tale of folklore character Harmon Teaster from the late 1800's, Dean's great,great, grandfather. It weaves a tale of part of his life with the theme park Ghost Town in the Sky, where Dean's father and Hebert "Cowboy" Coward acted with the group called "The Internationaly Famous Ghost Town Gunfighters". This group of eleven men were RB Coburn's gunfighter crew around 1961 through 1966. During this time they acted along side Hollywood greats such as Clu Gulager, Paul Fix, Frank McGrath, Burt Reynolds, Craig Hill, Donald May, Peter Brown, Veronica Cartwright, Dan Blocker, Tony Dow, John Broomfield, Jon Provost, Ken Weatherwax, Clint walker, Darby Hinton, Grant Sullivan, Larry Matthews, etc. Since Dean's father created the real character of "Digger the Undertaker" in the theme parks gunfights, he will also play the character "Digger" in the movie as a tribute to his late father Robert Doyle Teaster. Herbert Coward portrayed "Old Zeke" and "Grandpappy" in the gunfights as well, was discovered by Burt Reynolds on his visit to Ghost Town in 1963 when he played Quint Asper for the TV series "Gunsmoke". Burt Reynolds later called him for the part of the "Toothless Man" in Deliverance. Herbert "Cowboy" Coward lost his two front teeth in a gunfight at Ghost Town in 1962, when "Digger" was being played by a fill in person in Robert Teaster's absence. The replacement "Digger" accidentally hit Herbert "Cowboy" Coward in the mouth with a Colt 45, knocking his front teeth out in front of an estimated 5000 people watching the gunfight. DJ Perry, who wrote this screenplay was able to weave parts of the gunfighter history in with the Harmon Teaster Appalachian's folklore tale. This movie will also be released at the same time of the Theme park re-opening scheduled May 2007, where the "Ghost Town Partners" (new owners) headed up by Hank Woodburn will return the park back to the "Golden Years" vision of original builder, Mr. RB Coburn, the mastermind behind "Ghost Town in the Sky", "Frontierland", and "Six Gun Territory" in Ocala Florida.Alaska Presley, and her late husband Hugh Presley were instrumental in the opening and operation of Ghost Town in the Sky with RB Coburn, and Russ Pearson, and Uncle Dan Carpenter. Today, she is one of the executive producers of the movie Ghost Town.Robert Bradley, the original character "The Apache Kid", from the original crew of gunfighters is also an executive producer of the film.Harry Valentine, the "Golden Voice of Ghost Town", is an associate producer of the film and is responsible for making erecting a large polished granite memorial at Ghost Town along with the new owners of the theme park, to created a memorial to the original crew of gunfighters and the Hollywood greats who visited the park in the early years. The memorial will be dedicated to Robert Doyle Teaster, for his portrayal of the character "Digger the Undertaker", It will be placed in a waiting lounge area at the foot of the mountain where visitors wait to load the famous mile high chairlift and incline to the top of the mountain at Ghost Mountain Park.The movie will also Starr Stella Parton, Rance Howard, Charlie Mattheau, and a host of others.The movie was originally started by Dean Teaster as a documentary of the original gunfighters and the theme park "Ghost Town in the Sky". When DJ Perry was brought on board, the project was turned over to CDI and they teamed up and turned it into this movie.

Knowing this is a cult classic, I can't help being unamused and disappointed with this film. It has the potential to be amazing. Such a shame. Burt Reynolds is so cringe-worthy and completely let down by his middle-of-the-road co-stars. This film could have done with more brutality, and I'm not one for overly violent films. What it does offer is a fantastic picture and leaves you with the urge to get outdoors and have some fun. If you happen to enjoy outdoorsy, masculine, far fetched thrillers, you may just like it, but expect the worst and hope for the best. Personally, I couldn't sit through it ever again. I hope you get more enjoyment than I did.

i am only 13 years old but I've been a fan of horror movies since i was about 5. I love disturbing movies that shock your mind but this stands out more than any. The most disturbing films I've seen are Last House on the Left, I Spit on Your Grave, Salo, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Cannibal Ferox, Cannibal Holocaust and Deliverance. I saw I spit on Your grave before this and i thought it was a shocking and unbearable movie. I heard Deliverance was close to ISOYG so i checked it out. I loved it. I like the story: 4 city boys plan a canoe trip down the cahulawassee river and 2 of them are captured by 2 deranged inbred Hillbillys, and are tortured, raped and violated in the woods. It's not as unbearable as I spit on Your Grave and Last House on the Left but that "Squeal Like a Pig" rape scene is really disturbing. The Evil Rednecks scare you to death, and as soon as he rapes Ned Beatty you want to turn the TV off. But it's a superb film and i continue to watch it over and over again.

reviews.review_title: My own ramblings on the subject of Deliverance
reviews.content: Deliverance is John Boorman's 1972 horror/thriller movie about a group of four Atlanta businessmen (Burt Reynolds, Jon Voight, Ned Beatty and Ronnie Cox), that undertake a canoe trip down the Cahulawassee River before the river is dammed. Along the way, a raft (no pun intended) of unpleasant things happen to the men. Despite the nasty happenings in this picture, Boorman captures the natural beauty of the river nicely. The location was really chosen well. Indeed, this would still be a very nice film to watch, had the canoe trip gone smoothly. The lush forests and gentle landscape only make the horror more horrible. Not only is the location scenic, but also beautifully shot thanks to cinematographer Vilmos Zsigmond. It has been said that Burt Reynolds' performance as the outdoorsman, Lewis, is the star acting role in this film. I reckon however, that Jon Voight steals the show with his role as the suburban family man, Ed, who is rapidly forced to change his demeanour in order to survive. In fact, the scene in which climbs the cliff was not a stuntman. It was Voight himself. To cut costs the filming wasn't insured and the actors did their own stunts. The soundtrack is particularly noteworthy. Eric Weissberg's and Steve Mendel's performance on guitar and banjo as part of the Duelling Banjos sequence remains one of the most awesome pieces of soundtrack in the history of cinema for the sheer intensity of its performance. At a couple of other points in the movie, we are treated to more, softer, banjo music which provides a very pleasant accompaniment to the trip down the river For all the good points of this film, I did find it a little lacking in purpose. It doesn't build suspense very well and it isn't really as gruesome as we have been led to believe. The plot itself is somewhat poor and it doesn't really go anywhere. Nevertheless, this movie has enough good points to get my recommendation. I did like it but for fans of gore, there isn't really much of it. None really, in fact. It isn't so much a horror film as an adventure film that turns a little bit sour. Think of it like Rambo: First Blood meets Three Men In A Boat. Look out for a very young Charley Boorman as Ed's son. I did like this movie, the soundtrack, cinematography and acting earns it a well deserved 7 out of 10.

reviews.review_title: He's got a reeel purty mouth..
reviews.content: Absolute masterpiece incorporating superb levels of tension building throughout.Each of the four principal cast members are perfectly suited for their roles and Burt Reynolds gets a chance to show that he is really very gifted.Jon Voight beautifully makes the transision from affable stooge to Reynolds' "Lewis" to a man literally fighting for his life later on as events take a turn for the worse.I think he plays Ed with the just the right amount of internal confliction and sensitivity that is quite synominous in many of his performances and I rate him highly. With regards to "Alien Times" comment on his dislike for Voight, I wonder if he is thinking of the right actor as I cannot recall any appearence by Voight in The Deer Hunter...might want to check that one again.Praise to Cox and Beatty who also turn in solid performances.

reviews.review_title: The only Jon Voight film I can stand
reviews.content: This is not so much a review of Deliverance as a libellous diatribe about Jon Voight.  Every single film I have seen him in either sucks or is highly over-rated.  Or both.  Take for example The Deer Hunter, sentimental patriotic mush and pretentious to boot.  Then there's Coming Home, more or less the same movie only without the Russian Roulette.  Midnight Cowboy is the most overrated film ever, surely.  So the best thing about Deliverance is that somehow I can actually watch it despite Jon Voight's creeping, seeping presence.  And obviously the bit with the banjoes is fun and when the fat guy has to squeal like a pig.  The theme of man vs nature has been better done (even by Boorman) but it keeps the film the right side of sensationalist and its probably Burt Reynold's best film, unless you want to include Boogie Nights, obviously.

Many people in this age think of true movies as foul language, sex, and ultra violence with a few explosions thrown in. This movie proves that cinema has really changed over the last thirty years. The movie could not be made now. The story is mostly plausible albeit a little over the top in several sequences. All the performances are really superb, especially Voight as the conflicted Ed. The musical score is very catchy yet is creepy after watching the movie, sort of like The Exorcist's Tubular Bells. The cinematography is equally unnerving through its beauty and harshness. This is probably one of the most brutal movies you will ever see. This movie will haunt you for a REALLY long time.

reviews.review_title: Best intro for a movie so far.
reviews.content:
I've seen a load of movies. But this banjo opening scene beats 'm all.
Man, I came back over 20 times to just see that intro again. For the rest also a great movie. Not something you wanna watch with your kids though.
Words can't describe how lost and bad this movie was. My expectations weren't high for a 70s movie but this was bad.

well at the beginning of the film, everything is completely normal. we see four men, just taking some time out to go canoing somewhere in the outback, for time to unwind and relax, or maybe so, for a little adventure.But as the film goes on, things take a terrifying dive for the worse, as the four young men got a lot more than they bargained for, and as an audience we witness some of the finest acting which modern cinema lacks dramatically also while squirming in suspense at the some of the critical points in the movie.Of course the 2 highlights most critics would agree would be the famous duelling banjos scene, in which a retarded child takes on a musical duel with Ronny cox's character drew. and of course the other scene is the very controversial homosexual hillbilly rape, in which i dreaded as it built up to it, yet was unable to take my eyes off of the screen.the theme music through out the film, in a way sums up the epic tale, the riff played during the duelling guitar scene is played through out the film, but much slower.an undeniable superb piece of acting is john Voight's character, in which we see a truly normal ordinary man, put to the test as he has to use wits and skill, and even more, courage to actually survive the sinister villains. the retarded banjo boy who duels with cox's character drew at the beginning, is considered by most viewers as with out a doubt, the most sinister, despite him not doing anything bad to the men at all. i think its because he represents the villainous territory in which the men don't belong in, and i think the bit when they are flowing down stream and they see the boy on the bridge above, staring at them, thats when as an audience we see that there is a dark hidden evil in the outback.all in all, the film is intense, gritty, violent, morbid, and epic in general. the film is a dark journey through the great unknown which is hidden from the world, an evil not visible by the likes of 'city people'. a deteriorating world hidden out of sight, where there is simply a different way of life.superb film in all.9/10 - recommended

When a movie shocks you with it's disturbing, brooding atmosphere, and grabs you by the throat with it's stunning cinematography, you just know that you have stumbled upon a treat, masterpiece of a film. Although with most modern movies, extremely enjoyable as some are, those that really shock you into focus are the strongest, and are the ones that are most critically acclaimed and mostly, stick with you for a life time. I say, proudly, that I am a fan of movies that disturb, not just horror movies, but those that send a vibe laden with foreboding. Movies like Breakdown and The Missing, that send a chill down your spine, making you think "holy crap, that could happen to me", and visually entice you, are up there with some of my favorite aspects in a movie. Because I am only 21, I did not grow up with actors like Burt Renyolds, Jon Voight and Ned Beatty, albeit I am familiar with them, I didn't watch them grow and proceed as actors, as opposed to actors now like Shia LaBouf and Justin Long. I must say, after the long hype and witnessing Deliverance for the first time, I was so admired by these veteran actors in a movie made more than 30 years ago, and still lives it's terror up in competition to modern movies. Burt Renyolds plays Lewis, the macho self appointed leader of a group of four friends on a canoe trip down a fictitious river before a dam is made, filling the whole wilderness in water. Renyolds' character is an experienced adventurer, sort of no nonsense, and filled with machismo. Witnessing him portray the tough guy, made me think differently about him as an actor, as i have only seen him as a seedy old guy or an angry politician. The dialog the director provides for his character gives him enough malice to be proved as a strong and even intimidating leader. Ronny Cox and Ned Beatty play as the novice adventurers, Drew and Bob respectively, joining in for the fun of a canoe trip. The actor that i thoroughly enjoyed watching was Jon Voight, once again I have only seen him as an older actor, however, unlike Renyolds, I have quite liked Voight's acting (and i don't regard Anaconda when I say that), for example the national treasure movies. Voight plays Ed, whom, like Lewis, is experienced in adventuring but is seen as a more reserved character, a reluctant hero/ leader and definitely lacks Lewis' machismo. The film basically opens up with the four driving into a small town while asking to find someone to drive their cars to the bottom of the river whilst they canoe the rapids and camp along the riverside. You immediately get a creepy vibe from the hillbilly characters we are introduced to, like the imbred kid who plays the infamous "Duelling Banjo's" at the start of the film with Ronny Cox's character Drew; and more so the two mountain men in the films pivotal and disturbing rape scene. As with all atmospheric movies, from this moment on, dread and confusion fills the characters as well as the audience and it is here we see the characters take shape and change form. The canoe trip that follows is expertly shot and it is from here the men fight against both human and nature's odds for survival. The film's cinematics do not let up, and I back that comment up with the scene in which Ed fights one of the rapist mountain men with a composite bow. As Ed falls on to one of his arrows and notices his enemy approaching him, cocks his rifle, only to shoot the floor as he falls with an arrow in his neck; was possible the greatest piece of cinematic shooting I have seen in a film. In wrapping up, Deliverance is one film, who's dread and atmosphere carry the mood across and to this date, remains one of the best films in cinematic history.

Absolute cracker of a film, although getting along in years. Most famous for the dualling banjos theme and the graphic scene in the woods. All that aside, the part that did it for me was the broken leg near the end!! Errgggh!! How young does Burt Reynolds look in this movie?

Absolute cracker of a film, although getting along in years. Most famous for the duelling banjos theme and the graphic scene in the woods. All that aside, the part that did it for me was the broken leg near the end!! Errgggh!! How young does Burt Reynolds look in this movie?

reviews.review_title: A great movie- Why isn't it on the top 250?
reviews.content: (SPOILERS HERIN) My title says it all. This was a great movie! Yet, somehow, it isn't on the top 250, while it is far superior to at least half the list. Why is it so good? Well, for one thing, the simple amount of unforgettable parts in the film. The two hicks who rape our heroes are two of the most well-plaid movie villains of all time, and simply because of them, I am scared out of my mind to go in the woods! Get a Banjo and play "Dueling Banjos" in the woods sometime- it's a party. The scene in which that is played was a life-changing experience- after that, I tried to learn to play a Banjo. There is so much greatness in the film, and the only real complaint I hear is "It's overlong." My reply to this is "So What?" So are the Lord of the Rings movies, as are the Matrix, yet they're on the top 250. So, check this out- if you don't mind sitting down and watching a movie, it is quite good.

Rich in challenging themes and unthinkable moral dilemmas, John Boorman's Deliverance is the harrowing story of four men who embark on an ill-conceived canoe trip down a treacherous river in northern Georgia, confronted by dangerous rapids and unimaginable horror throughout their journey.  Filled with meaningful dialogue (‘Sometimes you have to lose yourself before you can find anything') and iconic moments (the spirited Dueling Banjos scene), Deliverance is an adventure movie like no other, a film that cemented Burt Reynolds star status and confirmed the considerable talent of Jon Voight.  On top of the star power, Vilmos Zsigmond's cinematography is stellar throughout, especially the shallow focus shots early in the movie.  While not always easy to watch, it is a movie that needs to be seen.
Never get off the boat

An unflinchingly directed piece of film that manages to be iconic even in its brutality, made even more impressive with the natural beauty of Georgia beauty and the collection of iconic actors paired with their lack of stuntmen.

Survival favors the strong in Deliverance which tells the story of four Atlanta businessmen who go to the wilderness but are being hunted. Near the beginning of the film, the music is quite catchy especially the scene where the little southern boy plays the banjo. The acting performances from Burt Reynolds and Ned Beatty are fantastic. The film is also quite spine-chilling especially the most infamous scene in the film. Deliverance is indeed a terrifying and chilling adventurous tale on how the strong will survive.
I always heard good things about this movie. So I gave it a shot. I don’t see what people considered so great about it. I thought it was boring and the writing was pretty awful.

this movie gets talked about a lot on how disturbing it is & i've heard interviews with Burt Reynolds saying they let the piggy scene go on for far too long; someone should've said something & stepped in. so i guess i was just expecting it to be much worse than it actually ended up being. it's not a bad movie at all, but i spent a lot of time thinking "that's it?" & then the movie was over. i don't think it has the same effect today as it might've in the 70's.
Brutal, horrifying and epic.

Perhaps I’ve missed something, but Deliverance seems to be more content delivering uncertainty than concrete results. Maybe that’s to the films benefit though. It’s not altogether a pleasant experience and I found the message to be a bit blurred. Considering the context that these city men went through, it was hard to see the backwoods characters as anything but awful. Maybe it’s better on multiple viewings. Just aspects of the story felt disjointed even if they were interesting

I watched this movie when I was young and then proceeded to "take this movie with me" often as my main hobby was hiking and I could not shake this movie every time I got into a secluded area. Since I spent a lot of time in secluded areas this movie was often sitting on my shoulder with me trying not to let it weigh me down. Thus this is one of the most impactful movies of my life. So interpret my thoughts that I found the movie very realistic and liable to happen in real life at any time to those enjoying the great outdoors in an isolated area.
A very impressive yet horrific vision of the wild

Film criticism is fluid and opinion of certain movies changes over time. Case in point – Deliverance. Whereas this must have been just another exploitation flick when it was released in the seventies, nowadays it's regarded as a thematically rich take on the damaging psychology of rape and how it's perceived in society, the dangers of machismo and the American culture war. Personally, the film walks a too fine line between just being a survival thriller and a sophisticated drama in my book. While its depiction of the complex power dynamics between men and the infamous rape are excellent, I find that most critics have gone too far in adding additional substance to it when it's not really there. The second half is particularly straightforward as this survival tale in a harsh natural landscape that, although superbly edited, directed, acted and shot, did seem a bit implausible and overly dire in many of its scenarios.

A powerful and brutal tale of psychological warfare as well as a physical fight for survival for four men in the middle of a very rural area with only a scant few people.  Burt Reynolds and Jon Voight star and give the heart of the performances in a great cast of characters and really convey depth to their given roles.  The film is a living nightmare and one in which the characters go from a relatively relaxed carefree mood to one in which their survival and fates are all up in the air.  The film is most famous for a particular scene involving the rape of one man by another (a deranged hillbilly out hunting) and is a powerful and extremely disturbing sequence that will stay with you long after you have viewed "Deliverance".  This film isn't for the easily upset or disturbed but if you can handle the material it's a powerful story with a profound impact on the viewer.
Saw it in the theater, decades later, and just now.  Excellent acting, but stereotypical plot with macho relationships.  Beautiful scenery with the ugly truth about damming up rivers.

This movie is considered a classic and is really known for a infamous male on male rape scene.  The movie uses a interesting camera style for the parts of the movie that have detailed dialogue where you feel like you're watching from a hidden camera.  I liked it, but at the same time it's a difficult watch.

Based on the best-selling book by James Dickey and starring Jon Voight, the late Burt Reynolds, Ronny Cox, and the late Ned Beatty 
4 men take a canoeing trip on Georgia to get away from their wives and work-reliant existence 
However, they are not welcomed by the backwoods locals, who stalk the vacationers and savagely attack them in the woods
Reeling from the ambush, the friends attempt to return home but are surrounded by dangerous rapids and pursued by a madman
Soon, their canoe trip turns into a fight for survival 
This sounds like your average horror-movie scenario yet 50 years on it started a trend of thrillers taking place in the backwoods countryside 
Director John Boorman exhibits a streak of defiant determination in the face of adversity 
The film stands as a powerful exploration of the harshness of the rural landscape, one with an ecological message that still resonates; that the destruction of the natural world has consequences for everyone
But the other aspect, one that has provoked a more divided response over the years, is its portrayal of "local" folk
In many ways, it defined a very particular branch of US cinema – one that became particularly popular in the 1970s, and expressed an abject fear of those who lived outside of cities 
The raw edgy stuff doesn't start until 50 min in and even after that it still goes at a snails pace just to get out alive 
The wilderness does provide a sense of isolation and dread I'll give it that 
And this director explores some very risky territory relying on savage instincts 
Still I feel this should've had more urgency or the very least some intense chase music 
This film feels so much longer than 108 min it's a bit agonizing 
Reynolds had his film debut here but he gets seriously sidelined 
But this is a terrifying adventure showing the horrors of life outside the city 
Not a movie specifically made for my taste and maybe others but I think the book does the material better

This is a shocking and riveting movie based on James Dickey's work about modern men seeking to rebel against the industrialization of the modern South and to commune with nature.   Their river rafting trip becomes a nightmare when things go wrong and they are forced to go from vacationing campers to survivalists.   The acting of the core cast, particularly, Reynolds is outstanding.   The visuals are frightening and John Boorman's Direction provides and eerie and appropriate tone for the story.  This one is dark and disturbing in many ways but makes some great points on the condition of modern man, and, possibly, the true nature of mankind.   There are some disturbing scenes, for sure, but this is worth watching.   This one holds up.

Shot in the mountains of northern Georgia, the story of four friends from Atlanta taking a canoe trip down a river that will be shortly submerged under a lake is beautiful at times, and harrowing at other times.  The natural surroundings are gorgeous, but there's people in those mountains that surround the river, and some of them are dangerous.  Roger Ebert disliked this film, but I'll disagree with him on this occasion.

A fantastic story and acting that is truly memorable.
It's a bit unfortunate that there are some cinematography issues during the night scenes.

As many times as I've seen "Deliverance," I must admit that I've never been entirely certain what the film is truly about. Yes, there are themes that stand out, such as the brutal process of self-discovery concurrent with running the gamut against the savage trials of nature, yet this is merely an intimation of a deeper meaning that I think can only be felt rather than understood. Boorman certainly makes deliberate decisions relative to story development that contribute to a truly one of a kind film-viewing experience, such as eschewing traditional plot structure including definitive beginning and endpoints, thus creating a sense of a living, evolving film that flows continuously like the river navigated by its protagonists. He places a striking emphasis on ambiguity, heightening a deep sense of unease relative to uncertainty and disorientation. Haunting images fleet across the screen, such as a mass exhumation of coffins in a soon to be flooded out cemetery and the towing of a solitary church along a country road. Utilizing such strange patchwork elements, "Deliverance" provides tantalizing suggestions of its thematic depth without fully giving the game away, leaving us in the midst of a graphic, disturbing, and undeniably galvanizing film experience. You will continue hearing the nagging plucks of the banjo long after the duel is over.

The movie that made Yankees and urbanites shake in their loafers, spawn countless parodies and stereotype a gigantic region of people, Deliverance is a harrowing tale of four "fish out of water" (or more accurately, four Atlanta businessmen very much in uncontrollable water) and their struggle for survival. The "dueling banjos" scene is such a lovely way to start the film, which makes you think we're going to get more mountain wholesomeness — couldn't be further from the truth. Instead, our crew of Lewis (Burt Reynolds), Ed (Jon Voigt), Bobby (Ned Beatty), and Drew (Ronny Cox) realize they are out of their element and not welcome in this Appalachian corner of Northeast Georgia — well, except for Lewis, who is our "return to the Earth," machismo survivalist who is probably more at home in Rabun County than DeKalb or Fulton. I've really had to ponder this film and a few of the directions the plot takes (I'm aware it's based on a book). Lewis getting sidelined for the third act was surprising, but I actually thought it was effective in completely changing our expectations for our protags' fate — you think, as long as they have Lewis, they'll be ok. On the other hand, I hated whatever the hell it was they did with Drew. He just jumps off the boat to his inevitable death? For what? Guilt not that he even murdered someone in obvious self-defense, not that he voted against not going to the police, but because he helped bury a body of a rapist?? That's ridiculous. Moreover, it made no sense to me that the group thought he was shot. Maybe have a tree branch crack or a hunter's gun go off contemporaneously with him diving into the water, but don't have it be this stupid. Yes, there's the rape scene we've all heard about long before we ever watched the movie — no one is being taken by surprise here. It's brutal. Hard to watch. In fact, I found it surprising that it didn't seem to mess with Bobby nearly enough — in the end, he seems to make the best out of the whole group! The production is infamous for not insuring the actors and having them perform most/all of their own stunts, which makes it even more impressive — Jon Voigt really climbed that cliff. The use of banjo in the score and the gorgeous shots of the river and mountains make it an aesthetically pleasing watch — the deformed inhabitants of the area, not so much. It's a must-watch for cinephiles, if you can stomach ass rape.
If the environment rises up.

I could see how it was a groundbreaking thriller in the 70s but by today’s standards I didn’t find it all that scary or thrilling. Burt Reynolds is fun to watch and the cast plays well together. And there are certainly some memorable scenes that will stick with me. Overall, entertaining and visually interesting, but there didn’t seem to be any interesting point made.

A master class in uncomfortable, Deliverance is a completely unique storyline that follows 4 men down the river. When they come across mountain men with no teeth, things get really bad and choices they're forced to make stretch their morality.

Great movie. Reynolds is your ruthless tough guy and Voight is your classic Everyman hero.  It's an interesting survival horror flick in how they come to the great outdoors for adventure, but compared to some of the savage locals, nature is blissfully peaceful. Decades later, it's most brutal scenes still make the modern viewer grimace: quite impressive.
Not a bad movie, but still lacking a real interest for me. The beginning is the most interesting part. The main plot is a bit strange really, though it's not terrible.
Your eyes won't leave the screen & no one with you will want to talk as this well-aged Classic slowly but surely unfolds into shock after shock after shock. Truly DELIVERS!

Beautifully shot, but extremely overrated and very boring. The opening scene gave me
"Texas Chainsaw" vibes, but that ended just as it started. One decent scene does not make a movie good. I recommend you skip this one!

The classic movie about the misadventures of a group of city slickers who head out to the wilds for a weekend canoeing an isolated river. Things do not go well and what was intended to be an adventure, turns into a fight for life.
Two things really stand out...Duelling Banjos and just how barmy Burt Reynolds is. His character is truly awful but he plays it so well.
Jon Boorman's films haven't always aged well but this is a real tour de force and still packs quite a punch.

Reasonably good movie. The Duelling Banjos scene is iconic and fantastic. Some scenes in this movie are genuinely disturbing but the acting is superb, even from Jon Voight who I normally can't stand. Main negative from my point of view would be that some of this feels slower than it needs to be. That said, it's still quite compelling overall and definitely worth watching. James Dickey (who wrote the screenplay based on his novel) appears in a minor role too.

I watched it about 15 years ago. Depressing, violent, and foul movie. I have no idea what the hype is about. But it has certainly ruined every small town for me. Invariably, now every single time I am driving through a small settlement the first thing that comes to mind is DELIVERANCE!!!

yes, it's true. Burt Reynolds could actually act. This is one of the best directed slices of deep-south Americana ever committed to film. The story is simple: four city-types head out into the woods and get terrorized by truly-frightening rednecks. Yet there is so much more going on in subtexts of the situation and the interplay with the characters that it demands multiple-viewings. That it took an Irish John Boorman to capture the dark side of parts of USA speaks volumes for his directing skills. The dueling banjo soundtrack is justly famous, and is one of the finest music interludes of all time...

After watching Deliverance for the first time only a short month ago, the movie produces a story of emotional significance far beyond its 'Dueling Banjos' cultural references. The way it is filmed, written, paced, all provided to the raw grit feeling that was left with me after I watched it. The film's work is not polished, and not quite compiled together in a smooth and seamless manner. But somehow this uncut, rugged nature of the film gives the story's dark concepts an added value that hit me hard as a viewer. Among these dark moments in the film, take the guitar-playing character Drew, when he falls from the boat and disappears into the churning water. There is no music, the camera keeps it's distance, and the moment is shrouded over by the sound of the river. It is in those moments, that the untouched emotional simplicity of the movie gave me a feeling that I've heard so many others recall when they saw this film, feelings of discomfort, shock, and realism. I believe this to be key characteristic to this film's great 50-year legacy.
The raw style Deliverance makes its name for does unfortunately have it's shortcomings. The film's simplicity continues to the story's very final moments, an area where the director and the screenwriter of the movie had an opportunity for blonde-mustache character Ed (for example) to offer a conclusive reflection to the horrors and hardship he saw and did. 
In conclusion, I think the film takes a firm side on the spectrum to the amount of explanation a director should provide his audience with, whether to make a movie that guides the viewer through the story's meaning, or one that only reveals its true value after a strong reflection by the audience. Whatever a movie critic may think about that choice though, I think few can deny having the lasting memory of this film that I have had.

Astonishingly brutal tale of an adventure gone wrong. Four fantastic lead performances along with John Boorman's gripping direction, help create a sense of genuine tension and horror as things start to unravel. With the way the cinematography is set up, you always feel like someone is watching them as they plunge down the Chattooga rapids. Jon Voight and Ned Beatty are immaculate in this.

Ahh, Deliverance. What an awesome film. Legendary director John Boorman (except for The Exorcist 2, what the hell was that?) utilises an all male cast, a very difficult novel to adapt to the big screen, breathtaking cinematography and amazing landscapes and creates a story of survival, violence and a man's psychological state when he is pushed to the limit, in a way similar to Peckinpah's controversial Straw Dogs, which came out the year before. The story concerns a quartet of city men, Lewis, Ed, Bobby and Drew, who plan to make a canoe trip to fictional Kahulawasse River before the surrounding area floods due to a dam. After a run in with the locals (the famous Dueling Banjos scene) they settle for the night near the river. The next day they decide to split up, a desicion that will leave them permanently scarred for the rest of the movie and their lives. Bobby and Ed are captured by two hillbillies who... rape Bobby (infamous rape scene here). Luckily, Drew and Lewis show up and manage to kill oone of the two. After that unfortunate incident they have to return to civilization through the rough and treacherous river. The screenplay, carefully written by author James Dickey, the dynamic quartet of actors and focused, tense direction by Boorman make every scene unforgettable and gripping, to the point where you want to look away but you are so enhanced by the carefull pacing that you can't. Even though I have some issues with character development and the glorification of violence, sexualised or not, I highly recommend watching this man VS nature story. However, it is not for the squeamish. 
Squeal like a pig.

It's almost 50 years old. It actually holds up decent. But it's about an hour's worth of plot stretched out to almost 2 hours. It's slow. Worth seeing once just because it's like a staple movie reference in American culture. But I wouldn't watch it again.

An outstanding thriller that skilfully sets up quickly, before going into brutal, unsettling territory that stays with you. Boorman's direction creates superb tension and the film goes at an unrelenting pace at times. With a strong soundtrack to boot and great performances all round this film ticks all the boxes for me.

I'm a firm believer that films don't need excess blood and gore to be disturbing or shocking.  Those sensations can come across purely by how the intense sequences are executed.  'Deliverance' excels in that aspect.  For a movie that's nearly 50 years old, it's pretty brutal in parts.  It's both a survival and rural odyssey through the Appalachian mountains that is heavy with moral dilemmas.  Thanks to some fine performances, the weight and burden of the justifiable homicides in self defense come across clearly.  Even if you have every right to save your life in the face of a guaranteed you-or-them threat, the situation can very well still haunt you.  On top of that, these characters being outsiders in a small mountain town does them no favors.  I noticed some parallels to 'Bone Tomahawk' in this film.  We have a group of guys making their way through unknown territory, surviving against cruel and sadistic savages, and one of our guys suffers a leg injury much like one of the titular characters in 'Bone Tomahawk' (although his was already there at the beginning of that film).  Not a carbon-copy influence, mind you, but it reminded me of that film nonetheless.  'Deliverance', despite expectedly dated imagery and some pacing issues in the first half, ends up being a really good and effective film that I do indeed recommend.
A good, dark and gripping film ... with special note for showing Burt Reynolds was not just a comedy actor, he really could play it straight

I like every character, what a true classic.
Still mesmerising after all these years - a a movie that plays the viewer like a fiddle... or a you know what! Outstanding.
